Primary working diagnosis: invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast (breast cancer).

Justification:
- New persistent breast lump for ~8 weeks with surrounding skin dimpling and progressive nipple retraction — classic signs of an underlying malignant breast mass causing tethering of Cooper’s ligaments and tissue retraction.
- Bloody (blood-tinged) nipple discharge and localized nipple redness also point to malignant involvement of ducts.
- Palpable ipsilateral axillary lymph node (small lump in left armpit) suggests regional nodal spread.
- Age (58), postmenopausal status, 5 years of hormone replacement therapy, skipped screening mammograms, and a family history of early-onset breast cancer in a first-degree relative increase her risk.
- Absence of pain or systemic symptoms does not exclude cancer; presentation is typical for invasive breast carcinoma (most commonly invasive ductal carcinoma).

Next steps would be urgent diagnostic workup (diagnostic mammography +/- ultrasound, core needle biopsy, staging as indicated).

Significant risk factors present in this case for breast cancer:

- Age 58 (increasing age)
- Nulliparity (never given birth)
- Personal use of menopausal hormone replacement therapy for ~5 years
- First-degree family history: sister with breast cancer at young age (age 31) — suggests possible genetic predisposition
- Missed mammography screening (skipped for 2 years) — delays detection
- Palpable axillary lymph node, skin dimpling, nipple retraction/discharge (clinical signs consistent with malignancy)

Less strong/possible risk: paternal family history of uterine cancer (may suggest familial cancer syndrome).

Summary diagnosis suspicion: invasive breast cancer (left breast) with possible nodal involvement. Immediate diagnostic steps, with rationale and how to perform:

1. Diagnostic mammography (bilateral, with spot compression and magnification of the left lesion)
- Why: more detailed radiographic evaluation than screening mammogram to characterize mass, calcifications, architectural distortion and to guide biopsy planning.
- How: obtain targeted craniocaudal and mediolateral oblique views plus additional spot compression/magnification views of the left breast and the area of concern; compare with any prior images (if available).

2. Diagnostic breast ultrasound (targeted to the palpable mass and axilla)
- Why: differentiates solid vs cystic lesion, assesses margins, vascularity, size, and evaluates axillary lymph nodes; guides core needle biopsy of nonpalpable or sonographically visible lesions.
- How: high-frequency linear transducer; scan the palpable area and axilla; document size, shape, echotexture, posterior features, and cortical thickness/hilum of nodes.

3. Image-guided core needle biopsy of the breast mass (preferably ultrasound-guided if lesion sonographically visible; stereotactic biopsy if only mammographic)
- Why: tissue diagnosis (histology, grade) is required to confirm malignancy and subtype; core biopsy yields sufficient tissue for receptor testing.
- How: percutaneous core needle (14–18 gauge) under ultrasound guidance for palpable/sonographic lesions; take multiple cores (usually 4–6); local anesthesia and sterile technique; send formalin-fixed tissue to pathology.

4. Core needle biopsy (or fine-needle aspiration combined with core) of suspicious axillary lymph node(s)
- Why: determines nodal metastasis preoperatively to stage and guide surgery/axillary management and neoadjuvant therapy decisions.
- How: ultrasound-guided core biopsy of suspicious node (cortex thickening, loss of fatty hilum); FNA can be used but core preferred for histology.

5. Pathology studies on biopsy specimens: histopathology, ER/PR, HER2 (IHC and reflex FISH if equivocal), Ki-67 when available
- Why: determines cancer type, receptor status and proliferation index which guide systemic therapy (endocrine therapy, HER2-targeted therapy, chemo).
- How: send tissue to pathology; order IHC for ER, PR, HER2; if HER2 IHC 2+, perform FISH.

6. Baseline breast MRI (contrast-enhanced) — selective use
- Why: evaluate extent of disease in the involved breast, detect multifocal/multicentric disease or contralateral occult tumor, useful if dense breasts, discrepant imaging, or planning breast-conserving surgery.
- How: gadolinium-enhanced breast MRI with dedicated coils; schedule after biopsy-related changes have settled (or interpret knowing post-biopsy enhancement).

7. Baseline staging workup if biopsy confirms invasive cancer and/or if clinically node-positive or higher stage (selective)
- Chest imaging (chest x-ray or CT chest), liver imaging (US or CT), bone scan or PET-CT
- Why: to evaluate for distant metastases if symptoms or high-risk features (large tumor, node-positive, high grade, aggressive subtype). Routine staging for early low-risk disease is not indicated.
- How: choose modality based on stage: PET-CT increasingly used for staging node-positive or stage III; bone scan if bone symptoms or high-risk features; CT chest/abdomen for suspected visceral disease.

8. Baseline labs
- Why: preoperative assessment and baseline prior to systemic therapy (CBC, CMP, LFTs, renal function). Tumor markers (CA 15-3/CEA) are not for diagnosis but may be used for baseline in advanced disease.
- How: standard venipuncture.

9. Genetic counseling and BRCA/BRCA-panel testing (given family history: sister with breast cancer at 31 and ovarian/uterine family history)
- Why: early-onset breast cancer in first-degree relative raises suspicion for hereditary breast/ovarian cancer syndrome; results affect surgical decisions (contralateral prophylactic mastectomy), systemic therapy, and family screening.
- How: refer to genetic counselor; arrange germline multigene panel (BRCA1/2 plus other relevant genes) prior to definitive surgery if possible.

10. Multidisciplinary referral and documentation
- Why: coordinate surgery, medical oncology, radiation oncology, pathology, and genetics for timely management.
- How: schedule expedited breast clinic or tumor-board review after biopsy results.

Perform these tests promptly, beginning with diagnostic mammography and ultrasound and proceeding immediately to image-guided core biopsy of the breast lesion and suspicious node.

For a BRCA2 carrier with invasive, ER-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer staged clinically cT2 (tumor >2 cm but ≤5 cm), cN+ (clinically node-positive), M0, immediate therapeutic strategies include local-regional therapy (surgery ± radiation) and systemic therapy (neoadjuvant vs adjuvant). Because she is node-positive and tumor size T2, current practice commonly favors neoadjuvant systemic therapy to downstage disease, evaluate response, and guide surgical decisions. Below are the principal options, timing, rationale, and alternatives.

1) Neoadjuvant endocrine therapy (NET)
- When to use: For ER-positive, HER2-negative disease in postmenopausal patients, especially with lower proliferation (luminal A–like), NET is an acceptable first-line neoadjuvant option. It is particularly appropriate if the goal is to shrink tumor to allow breast-conserving surgery and if tumor is strongly ER-positive and not highly proliferative.
- How to perform: Start an aromatase inhibitor (AI) — e.g., letrozole 2.5 mg daily, anastrozole 1 mg daily, or exemestane 25 mg daily — for 3–6 months, monitoring clinical response by exam and imaging (mammogram/US; MRI if needed). Reassess at ~3 months; continue to 4–6 months if response is ongoing. Manage bone health (calcium, vitamin D, DEXA) and review thrombotic risks.
- Rationale: NET is effective in postmenopausal ER+ tumors to achieve meaningful downsizing with relatively low toxicity.
- Alternatives / when not indicated: If tumor is high-grade, rapidly progressive, clinically bulky nodes, or ER expression is low/weak, NET alone may be less effective. In patients desiring rapid downstaging or with more aggressive features, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is preferred.

2) Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT)
- When to use: Preferred for node-positive disease when tumor biology suggests likely chemo benefit — e.g., higher grade, high proliferation (Ki-67), or if rapid cytoreduction is desired to facilitate breast-conserving surgery or to attempt nodal clearance. Also considered when NET is unlikely to be effective (low ER expression).
- How to perform: Typical regimens for ER+/HER2− include an anthracycline and taxane-based regimen (e.g., dose-dense AC [doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide] ×4 cycles followed by paclitaxel or docetaxel ×4 cycles) or docetaxel/cyclophosphamide regimens per institutional protocols. For node-positive disease, 4–6 months of systemic chemotherapy prior to surgery is usual. Monitor blood counts, cardiac function (if anthracycline), and toxicities.
- Rationale: NACT can downstage both breast and axilla; pathologic complete response (pCR) rates are lower in ER+ tumors than triple-negative/HER2+, but chemo can still reduce tumor and nodal disease burden and informs prognosis.
- Alternatives / when not indicated: If patient is frail, has comorbidities precluding chemo, or if tumor is very endocrine responsive, NET may be used instead.

3) Surgery (timing depends on neoadjuvant response)
- When to perform: If neoadjuvant therapy is given, surgery is planned after completion and reassessment (typically after 3–6 months). If upfront surgery is chosen (see below), perform promptly after staging workup.
- Type of surgery:
  - Breast: For BRCA2 carriers, strong consideration for bilateral mastectomy (therapeutic ipsilateral mastectomy plus contralateral risk-reducing mastectomy) because of high lifetime contralateral risk; however, patient preference, tumor size relative to breast, feasibility of breast-conserving surgery (BCS), and willingness for surveillance should be discussed. If breast conservation is feasible after neoadjuvant therapy and patient prefers BCS, wide local excision (lumpectomy) with clear margins plus whole-breast radiation is acceptable. If BCS is not feasible or patient prefers risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy, proceed to mastectomy ± immediate reconstruction.
  - Axilla: For clinically node-positive at presentation, standard is axillary staging/treatment after neoadjuvant therapy: if nodes clinically/ultrasound positive and become clinically node-negative after NACT, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) with dual tracer and retrieval of ≥3 sentinel nodes or targeted axillary dissection (TAD — removal of clipped node plus SLNB) may be used to avoid full axillary dissection. If residual node-positive disease at surgery, axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) is indicated. If upfront surgery chosen, ALND is standard for clinically node-positive disease (some centers will biopsy and clip positive node preop and may do targeted approach).
- Alternatives: Upfront surgery is an option if patient prefers immediate removal or if neoadjuvant therapy is contraindicated. In that case, mastectomy vs BCS discussion and routine ALND for cN+ disease are typical; post-op systemic therapy then given based on pathology.

4) Adjuvant systemic therapy (postoperative) — when neoadjuvant not given or based on pathology
- Endocrine therapy: All ER+ postmenopausal patients should receive endocrine therapy. Standard is an aromatase inhibitor for at least 5 years (e.g., letrozole). Extended endocrine therapy to 10 years may be considered based on risk factors (node positivity, tumor size, grade).
- Chemotherapy: If not given neoadjuvantly, adjuvant chemo is recommended for higher-risk ER+ node-positive disease (decision guided by tumor grade, nodal burden, genomic assays in selected cases). For BRCA2 carriers, chemo choices are same as above.
- CDK4/6 inhibitors: In the adjuvant setting, abemaciclib added to endocrine therapy is indicated for high-risk, node-positive, early-stage ER+/HER2− patients (e.g., ≥4 positive nodes, or 1–3 nodes with tumor size ≥5 cm or grade 3) per trial data and guidelines — check eligibility and label. Dose and duration per approved regimen (e.g., abemaciclib for 2 years). If contraindicated, endocrine therapy alone or other strategies apply.
- PARP inhibitor (olaparib): For germline BRCA carriers with high-risk, HER2-negative early breast cancer who received neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemo and have residual disease or for high-risk node-positive disease, adjuvant olaparib for 1 year is indicated based on OlympiA trial. Specific indications: patients with germline BRCA1/2 pathogenic variant and high-risk features (e.g., node-positive disease or residual disease after neoadjuvant chemo). Sequence with other adjuvant agents should be coordinated (start after recovery from surgery/chemo), and avoid concurrent strong CYP3A inducers/inhibitors.
- Radiation therapy: After BCS, whole-breast irradiation is standard. After mastectomy, postmastectomy radiation is indicated for high-risk features (≥4 positive nodes, or 1–3 nodes depending on tumor size/other factors). For patients treated with neoadjuvant therapy, indications for post-op chest wall or regional nodal radiation depend on pre-treatment stage and final pathology — the pre-treatment nodal status often guides need for regional radiation.
- Timing/sequencing: If neoadjuvant therapy given, surgery follows, then adjuvant radiation (if indicated) and further systemic therapy (endocrine therapy is usually started after completion of chemo/radiation as appropriate). Olaparib is typically started after completion of local therapy and chemotherapy or as per trial guidance — coordination with other agents (e.g., abemaciclib) requires multidisciplinary planning.

5) Genetic-related considerations and risk-reducing strategies
- BRCA2 carriers should be counseled about contralateral risk and risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction as an option; discuss timing (can be at time of therapeutic surgery) and fertility/menopausal implications already relevant.
- Consideration of bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for ovarian cancer risk reduction (generally recommended by age ~40–45 or after childbearing) should be discussed with gynecologic oncology/genetics.

6) Supportive care and staging/workup
- Complete staging (baseline CT chest/abdomen/pelvis or PET-CT) is not routinely required for non-suspicious clinical exam but consider imaging if symptoms or high-risk features. Bone scan if bone symptoms or high-risk features.
- Cardiac evaluation (echocardiogram/MUGA) prior to anthracycline or trastuzumab if indicated.
- Clip biopsy-proven positive node prior to neoadjuvant therapy to allow TAD if converting to node-negative.

Summary of likely immediate plan for this patient:
- Multidisciplinary tumor board discussion.
- Because she is postmenopausal, ER+, HER2−, cT2 cN+ and BRCA2-positive: options are
  - Preferred: Neoadjuvant systemic therapy — choose between NET (aromatase inhibitor for 3–6 months) if tumor is strongly ER-driven/low proliferation and patient wishes to avoid chemo; or NACT (anthracycline + taxane) if higher grade, higher Ki-67, or desired rapid response. Clip positive axillary node before systemic therapy.
  - After systemic therapy: surgical resection (BCS if downstaged and feasible, otherwise mastectomy; consider bilateral mastectomy given BRCA2 status), axillary staging/ALND or TAD per response.
  - Adjuvant: endocrine therapy (AI) for at least 5 years; consider adjuvant abemaciclib if high-risk per criteria; as a BRCA2 carrier with node-positive disease, adjuvant olaparib for 1 year should be strongly considered if she meets high-risk criteria (especially if residual disease after neoadjuvant chemo or if high-risk pathology after surgery).
  - Radiation as indicated based on surgery and nodal status.
All steps require individualized discussion of risks/benefits, fertility/menopause issues, and patient preferences.

With four positive axillary lymph nodes (N2 disease by older classification; ≥4 nodes positive), the appropriate treatment is completion axillary lymph node dissection (if not already done) followed by adjuvant systemic therapy and regional radiotherapy. Specifically:

- Complete axillary lymph node dissection (if sentinel biopsy only was done) or ensure adequate nodal clearance.  
- Adjuvant chemotherapy (typically indicated for node-positive disease in a 58-year-old).  
- Consider endocrine therapy (tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor) if the tumor is hormone receptor–positive.  
- Postmastectomy or whole-breast radiotherapy with regional nodal irradiation (including axilla/SCV) to treat residual nodal disease.

Final plan should be individualized based on tumor receptor status (ER/PR/HER2), comorbidities, and multidisciplinary tumor board discussion.

Recommended surveillance and follow-up after treatment for invasive breast cancer (per major guidelines — e.g., ASCO, NCCN, ESMO):

1. Clinical follow-up
- History and physical exam every 3–6 months for the first 3 years after primary treatment, then every 6–12 months for years 4–5, then annually thereafter. Exams focus on breast/chest wall, regional nodes, treatment-related toxicities, and psychosocial issues.

2. Mammographic surveillance
- Annual digital mammography of the conserved breast(s): first mammogram 6–12 months after completion of radiation (or baseline post-op mammogram if mastectomy not performed), then yearly thereafter.
- For patients with unilateral mastectomy, annual imaging of the remaining breast.
- Consider supplemental imaging (breast MRI/US) for high-risk features per guidelines (e.g., known genetic mutation, extremely dense breasts).

3. Surveillance for recurrence/metastasis
- Routine laboratory tests, tumor markers, or imaging (CT, bone scan, PET) are NOT recommended in asymptomatic patients for surveillance.
- Perform directed imaging or labs only for new signs/symptoms suggesting local, regional, or distant recurrence.

4. Contralateral breast and risk-reduction
- Annual clinical breast exam and annual imaging of the contralateral breast. Consider genetic counseling/testing if personal or family history suggests hereditary risk (young relative with breast cancer, strong family history); discuss risk-reducing options if mutation found.

5. Management of therapy effects and survivorship care
- Monitor and manage adjuvant therapy side effects (endocrine therapy, chemo/radiation toxicities), bone health (DEXA scan as indicated for aromatase inhibitor users), cardiovascular risk (as indicated), lymphedema surveillance and rehabilitation, psychosocial support, sexual health, and menopausal symptom management.
- Vaccinations and general preventive care per age-appropriate guidelines.

6. Patient education
- Teach breast self-awareness (report new lumps, skin changes, nipple changes, localized pain, or systemic symptoms promptly).

7. Coordination of care
- Provide a survivorship care plan documenting treatments received, follow-up schedule, who to contact for concerns, and recommendations for health maintenance.

Note: Individual follow-up may be tailored based on stage, treatments received, comorbidities, genetic test results, and patient preferences.

Main differential diagnoses to consider (besides primary breast carcinoma) and how to differentiate them from breast cancer by history, exam, and investigations:

1) Fibroadenoma
- Typical presentation: Usually in younger women (teens–30s), well-defined, rubbery, mobile, painless “breast mouse”; size may vary with hormones.
- Exam: Smooth, discrete, freely mobile, non-tender mass with no skin or nipple changes and no axillary nodes.
- Imaging/biopsy: Ultrasound: well-circumscribed, oval, hypoechoic lesion with parallel orientation; mammogram: round/oval, well-defined density, sometimes calcifications. Core needle biopsy (or excisional biopsy if uncertain) shows biphasic stromal and epithelial proliferation. Less likely in a 58‑year‑old new fixed/dimpled lesion.

2) Fibrocystic change / breast cyst
- Typical presentation: Cyclical breast pain/tenderness, lumpiness that fluctuates with cycle; cysts can be tender and fluctuate in size.
- Exam: Smooth, fluctuant, often multiple or bilateral lesions; no persistent skin tethering or bloody nipple discharge.
- Imaging/biopsy: Ultrasound: simple cyst = anechoic, thin-walled with posterior acoustic enhancement; mammogram: may show round/oval density; fine-needle aspiration yields straw-colored fluid and resolution of the lump. Persistent solid components or bloody aspirate → core biopsy to exclude cancer.

3) Intraductal papilloma / ductal ectasia
- Typical presentation: Unilateral nipple discharge (often serous or bloody) in perimenopausal or older women; small subareolar mass or no palpable mass.
- Exam: May have localized subareolar mass, sometimes nipple retraction or discharge; usually minimal skin changes.
- Imaging/biopsy: Ductography or ultrasound may identify intraductal mass; mammogram can be normal or show retroareolar density; duct excision or core biopsy (or nipple duct cytology) required to exclude associated malignancy.

4) Fat necrosis
- Typical presentation: History of trauma or prior surgery/radiation; firm, irregular mass can mimic cancer; may have skin retraction or ecchymosis.
- Exam: Usually hard, sometimes tender, may be superficial with skin retraction.
- Imaging/biopsy: Mammogram: oil cysts, calcifications; ultrasound: complex cystic/solid lesion. Core biopsy shows lipid-laden macrophages, fat crystals, and hemorrhage, excluding malignancy.

5) Mastitis / breast abscess
- Typical presentation: Painful, red, warm, swollen breast often with systemic symptoms (fever); common in lactating women but can occur in others.
- Exam: Tender, erythematous, fluctuant area if abscess; usually acute course.
- Imaging/biopsy: Ultrasound identifies fluid collection; aspiration yields purulent fluid and responds to antibiotics/drainage. Nonresolving inflammatory mass or inflammatory signs without infection → biopsy to rule out inflammatory carcinoma.

6) Phyllodes tumor
- Typical presentation: Rapidly enlarging, usually painless, well-circumscribed large mass in middle‑aged women.
- Exam: Large, mobile or slightly fixed mass; may stretch skin.
- Imaging/biopsy: Mammogram/US show large circumscribed mass; core biopsy may suggest but excisional biopsy required for definitive diagnosis and to assess malignant potential.

7) Benign breast calcifications / sclerosing adenosis / radial scar
- Typical presentation: Often asymptomatic, detected on screening mammogram; can mimic carcinoma radiologically.
- Exam: Often no palpable mass.
- Imaging/biopsy: Mammographic microcalcifications or architectural distortion; core biopsy needed to differentiate from DCIS/invasive cancer.

8) Metastasis to breast or lymphoma
- Typical presentation: Breast metastasis from other primaries is rare; often multiple, rapidly growing, firm masses; lymphoma may present as painless mass, sometimes bilateral.
- Exam: May be multiple lesions, less desmoplastic reaction, usually less skin dimpling.
- Imaging/biopsy: Core biopsy with immunohistochemistry (IHC) to identify non-breast origin or lymphoid markers; staging to find primary.

How to prioritize and investigate in this patient:
- Given age (58), new persistent lump, skin dimpling, nipple retraction, bloody discharge and axillary node — high index for carcinoma.
- Urgent bilateral diagnostic mammogram + targeted breast ultrasound.
- If imaging suspicious (BI-RADS 4–5) or discordant with exam, perform core needle (image-guided) biopsy of mass and any suspicious nodes; biopsy of nipple discharge or duct excision if isolated discharge.
- If imaging equivocal (cyst on ultrasound), consider FNA with cytology and repeat imaging after aspiration.
- Additional: MRI if multifocal/multicentric disease suspected or dense breast tissue, and staging workup (axillary ultrasound, sentinel node biopsy or node FNA) if cancer confirmed.
- Use histology and IHC (ER/PR/HER2) to confirm primary breast carcinoma and rule out other pathologies.

In short: clinical clues (age, pain, mobility, skin/nipple changes, systemic signs, history of trauma or lactation) guide initial suspicion; imaging (diagnostic mammogram + ultrasound) refines differential; tissue diagnosis (core biopsy ± node biopsy, cytology) is definitive.

Primary working diagnosis: lung cancer (most likely bronchogenic carcinoma).

Justification:
- Age (65) and significant smoking history (former smoker) are strong risk factors for lung cancer.
- Symptoms—persistent cough, progressive dyspnea, unexplained weight loss, chest pain—are classic systemic and local features of lung malignancy.
- Hemoptysis (coughing up blood) is a red flag sign commonly seen with bronchogenic carcinoma.
- COPD and hypertension are comorbidities that commonly coexist with smoking-related lung cancer and increase suspicion.
- Duration (two months) and progressive nature favor a malignant process over an acute respiratory infection.

Next steps would include chest imaging (CXR then chest CT) and urgent referral for bronchoscopy/biopsy to confirm diagnosis.

Primary working diagnosis: lung cancer (bronchogenic carcinoma).

Significant risk factors from the case:
- Age 65 (increased risk with older age)
- Former smoker (history of tobacco use)
- COPD (chronic lung disease increases lung cancer risk)
- Male sex (higher incidence historically)
- Unexplained weight loss, hemoptysis, persistent cough and chest pain are red-flag symptoms supporting the diagnosis (not risk factors but relevant clinical features).

Likely working diagnosis: lung cancer (given age, smoking history, progressive cough, weight loss, hemoptysis) with COPD background. Immediate diagnostic workup should aim to confirm malignancy, stage disease, assess fitness for procedures/therapy, and exclude other causes (infection, TB).

1) Vital signs, pulse oximetry, basic bedside assessment
- Why: assess stability, need for urgent oxygen, or acute intervention for hemoptysis.
- How: measure BP, HR, RR, temperature, SpO2 on room air.

2) Focused history and exam
- Why: localize symptoms, evaluate risk factors, look for metastasis (clubbing, lymphadenopathy, neurologic deficits, bone tenderness).
- How: targeted pulmonary, cardiac, neurological and lymph node exam.

3) Chest radiograph (PA and lateral)
- Why: rapid, accessible initial imaging to identify mass, consolidation, collapse, cavitation, pleural effusion.
- How: obtain upright PA and lateral views.

4) Contrast-enhanced chest CT (CT chest with IV contrast, including upper abdomen)
- Why: best initial cross-sectional imaging to characterize a pulmonary lesion (size, location, central v. peripheral), evaluate mediastinal nodes, chest wall/pleural involvement and to look for liver/adrenal metastases when abdomen included.
- How: multislice CT with IV contrast; include adrenal glands and upper abdomen if staging suspected.

5) Laboratory tests (baseline)
- CBC with differential
  - Why: anemia (blood loss from hemoptysis), leukocytosis (infection), baseline for therapy.
- Basic metabolic panel (electrolytes, renal function)
  - Why: baseline for contrast/chemotherapy.
- Liver function tests (AST, ALT, ALP, bilirubin)
  - Why: baseline and metastasis evaluation.
- Coagulation profile (PT/INR, aPTT)
  - Why: assess bleeding risk before invasive biopsy given hemoptysis.
- Arterial blood gas if hypoxic
  - Why: assess gas exchange and need for oxygen therapy.

6) Sputum studies
- Sputum cytology (preferably early morning samples, repeat x3)
  - Why: noninvasive method to detect central endobronchial tumors (sensitivity higher for squamous and small cell).
  - How: collect deep cough samples; send for cytology.
- Sputum Gram stain and culture, AFB smear/culture/PCR for TB if indicated
  - Why: rule out infection/tuberculosis as alternative cause of hemoptysis.
  - How: standard microbiology processing.

7) Flexible bronchoscopy with bronchial washings, brushings and endobronchial biopsy
- Why: diagnostic for central lesions and for sampling endobronchial masses causing hemoptysis; allows local control of bleeding if needed.
- How: perform under conscious sedation or general anesthesia; obtain visual inspection and targeted biopsies; send tissue for histopathology, immunohistochemistry and microbiology.
- Notes: urgent if massive hemoptysis or airway compromise.

8) Image-guided percutaneous transthoracic needle biopsy (CT-guided) of peripheral lung lesion if bronchoscopy non-diagnostic or lesion peripheral
- Why: obtain histologic diagnosis for peripheral masses not reachable by bronchoscopy.
- How: CT-guided core needle biopsy with appropriate imaging and post-procedure chest x-ray to detect pneumothorax.

9) Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS)-guided transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) of mediastinal/hilar lymph nodes
- Why: minimally invasive sampling for diagnosis and mediastinal staging (N staging) important for treatment planning.
- How: perform EBUS-TBNA during bronchoscopy; send samples for cytology, histology, molecular testing.

10) PET-CT (FDG PET/CT)
- Why: whole-body metabolic imaging for staging (distant metastases), to select biopsy site, and to evaluate mediastinal nodes (complementary to EBUS).
- How: perform after tissue diagnosis is planned or obtained; note false positives (infection/inflammation).

11) Brain imaging (MRI preferred; CT if MRI unavailable)
- Why: detect brain metastases for staging in symptomatic or stage II–IV disease; MRI is more sensitive.
- How: contrast-enhanced MRI brain.

12) Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) including spirometry, DLCO, and 6-minute walk test or cardiopulmonary exercise testing if needed
- Why: assess baseline lung function and surgical candidacy (e.g., predicted postoperative FEV1/DLCO).
- How: outpatient PFT lab with measurement of FEV1, FVC, DLCO; exercise testing if borderline.

13) Cardiac evaluation (ECG, echocardiogram if indicated)
- Why: baseline cardiac risk assessment prior to surgery or chemoradiation.
- How: resting ECG; echo if cardiac symptoms or abnormal ECG.

14) Tissue pathology with histologic subtyping and biomarker/molecular testing on tumor specimen
- Why: guide systemic therapy (especially for non-small cell lung cancer, NSCLC). Important biomarkers: PD-L1 expression, EGFR mutations, ALK rearrangement, ROS1, BRAF V600E, MET exon 14 skipping, RET, NTRK, KRAS, and others per guideline; also testing for microsatellite instability/ tumor mutational burden when indicated.
- How: send formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue for histopathology and immunohistochemistry (TTF-1, p40/p63 to distinguish adenocarcinoma v. squamous) and perform reflex next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel covering actionable mutations and FISH/ISH for rearrangements; perform PD-L1 immunohistochemistry.

15) External laboratory tumor markers (adjunctive, not diagnostic): serum CEA in adenocarcinoma can be measured
- Why: not diagnostic but can provide baseline for follow-up.
- How: routine serum assay.

16) Microbiology and special tests if hemoptysis/infection suspected
- Why: exclude bronchiectasis, lung abscess, TB, or fungal disease.
- How: targeted imaging/sputum cultures, PCR, and bronchoscopic sampling.

17) Other: referral for multidisciplinary team (thoracic surgery, medical oncology, radiation oncology, pulmonology, radiology, pathology)
- Why: integrate results, decide biopsy route and definitive staging and treatment.

Priority/sequence in an urgent outpatient setting:
- Immediate: vitals/oxygen, chest x-ray, CBC/coagulation, sputum for cytology and microbiology.
- Next (within days): contrast chest CT, bronchoscopy with EBUS-TBNA or CT-guided biopsy to obtain tissue for histology and molecular testing, baseline labs and PFTs.
- After tissue diagnosis: PET-CT and brain MRI for staging; molecular/biomarker testing on tumor tissue (NGS, PD-L1).

Note: Choice and order depend on clinical stability, lesion location (central v. peripheral), availability, and hemoptysis severity.

Staging summary and treatment intent
- cT2 cN1 M0 NSCLC (adenocarcinoma) in a 65‑year‑old with resectable disease — this is stage II (specifically stage IIA or IIB depending on tumor size; cT2 N1 → stage IIB in AJCC 8th typically). The goal is curative therapy.

Immediate therapeutic strategy — multimodality approach
1) Primary surgical resection (preferred if patient is operable)
- What: Anatomic lobectomy with systematic mediastinal and hilar lymph node dissection or systematic sampling.
- When/how: Perform as soon as patient is optimized surgically (pulmonary function, cardiac risk, smoking cessation, treat COPD exacerbations). Preoperative staging (PET‑CT, brain MRI if indicated) and invasive nodal staging (EBUS or mediastinoscopy) should be completed before surgery to confirm resectability and nodal status.
- Rationale: For resectable cT2N1 disease, lobectomy + node dissection offers best chance of cure.
- Alternatives if not amenable to lobectomy:
  - If marginal pulmonary reserve or high surgical risk: consider sublobar resection (segmentectomy) only for small peripheral tumors meeting criteria, but N1 disease usually favors lobectomy; if not possible, discuss risk/benefit with thoracic surgery and consider non‑surgical options below.
  - If medically inoperable: definitive concurrent chemoradiation (see below).

2) Perioperative systemic therapy
- Adjuvant chemotherapy (standard after complete resection for pathologic stage II)
  - What: Platinum‑based doublet (most commonly cisplatin + vinorelbine or cisplatin + pemetrexed for nonsquamous) for 4 cycles.
  - When: Start within ~4–8 weeks postoperatively once the patient has recovered sufficiently.
  - Rationale: Reduces risk of recurrence and improves overall survival for node‑positive disease.
  - Alternative if cisplatin not tolerated: carboplatin‑based doublet (less efficacious but used if renal/hearing/performance limitations).
- Perioperative immunotherapy considerations given PD‑L1 45%:
  - Adjuvant PD‑1/PD‑L1 therapy after chemo: For completely resected stage II–IIIA NSCLC with PD‑L1 expression, adjuvant atezolizumab has regulatory approval following adjuvant platinum chemo for PD‑L1 ≥1% (IMpower010). Another option is adjuvant pembrolizumab depending on guideline/regional approvals and trial results—check local approvals. Administer per label (e.g., atezolizumab every 3 weeks for 1 year) starting after completion of adjuvant chemo and adequate recovery.
  - Neoadjuvant chemo ± immunotherapy: Some centers use neoadjuvant platinum‑doublet ± immune checkpoint inhibitor for resectable stage II–III to increase pathologic response rates (e.g., nivolumab + chemo, pembrolizumab + chemo in trials). If chosen, give 2–3 cycles preoperatively with careful coordination; surgery then follows after imaging and recovery. This is an alternative to immediate upfront surgery when multidisciplinary team prefers neoadjuvant approach (e.g., to downstage bulky N1 or borderline resectable disease).
  - If patient is unfit for chemo: consider adjuvant immunotherapy alone only if supported by evidence/approval in your region (most approvals require prior adjuvant chemo); otherwise discuss observation vs clinical trials.

3) Radiation therapy
- Role perioperatively:
  - Postoperative radiotherapy (PORT): Not routinely indicated for completely resected N1 disease — benefit is controversial and typically reserved for R1/R2 resection or extracapsular nodal extension or high‑risk recurrences. If positive margins (R1/R2) or unresectable nodal disease, give PORT to mediastinum (conformal IMRT) typically after chemo or integrated with systemic therapy per timing protocols.
  - Definitive chemoradiation (non‑surgical option): If patient is not a surgical candidate, recommend concurrent platinum‑based chemoradiation to 60–66 Gy with concurrent chemo, then consider consolidation immunotherapy (e.g., durvalumab) for unresectable stage III per PACIFIC trial.
- When/how: Radiotherapy planning by multidisciplinary team; if PORT indicated, start after patient has recovered from surgery and typically after adjuvant chemo (timing individualized).

4) Management of comorbidities and supportive care
- Optimize COPD (bronchodilators, pulmonary rehab), control hypertension, smoking cessation, pulmonary physiotherapy to improve operative candidacy and reduce complications.
- Address hemoptysis as needed (bronchoscopy, embolization) prior to surgery if active significant bleeding.

Sequence summary (typical preferred pathway)
- If operable and patient fit: complete preop staging → upfront lobectomy + systematic node dissection → adjuvant cisplatin‑based chemo (4 cycles) → adjuvant immunotherapy (e.g., atezolizumab for 1 year) if indicated/approved and patient PD‑L1 45% supports benefit.
- Alternative pathway (neoadjuvant): multidisciplinary decision to give neoadjuvant platinum‑doublet chemotherapy +/- checkpoint inhibitor (per institutional practice/trials) → restage → surgical resection → adjuvant therapy based on pathology.
- If medically inoperable/unresectable: definitive concurrent chemoradiation → consolidation durvalumab (if PD-L1 and other criteria met) for unresectable stage III.

Genomic testing and other considerations
- Obtain molecular profiling (EGFR, ALK, ROS1, BRAF, etc.) on tumor tissue — though adjuvant targeted therapies are mainly for resected EGFR‑mutant disease (osimertinib) or ALK in trials; these results can influence systemic options.
- PD‑L1 45% supports immunotherapy benefit but does not replace need for chemo in perioperative settings per current evidence.

If first‑line options not indicated
- If poor performance status or comorbidities preclude chemo/surgery: consider stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) for small peripherally located tumors (but N1 disease typically not SBRT), palliative radiation for symptoms, or best supportive care. Consider enrollment in clinical trials when available.

Multidisciplinary coordination
- All decisions should be made in a thoracic multidisciplinary tumor board (thoracic surgery, medical oncology, radiation oncology, pulmonology, radiology, pathology) and tailored to the patient’s fitness and preferences.

For non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) after completion of initial definitive therapy (surgery, definitive chemoradiation, or stereotactic body radiation therapy), current guideline-based surveillance and follow-up recommendations focus on early detection of recurrence and second primary lung cancers, management of treatment complications, and assessment of functional status and supportive care needs. Key elements:

1. History and physical exam
- Frequency: every 3–6 months for the first 2 years, then every 6 months during years 3–5, then annually after year 5. (Some individualization allowed based on risk, symptoms, comorbidity and patient preference.)

2. Imaging
- Chest CT with contrast (or noncontrast if contrast contraindicated) of the chest every 6 months for the first 2 years, then annually up to 5 years. Many centers obtain CT every 6 months ×2 years then yearly.
- If patient had limited-stage disease treated with curative intent, consider CT of the chest ± upper abdomen per local protocol. PET/CT or brain MRI is not recommended routinely for asymptomatic surveillance but should be obtained when recurrence is suspected or for staging of new symptoms.
- After stereotactic body radiotherapy or surgery when postoperative changes make interpretation difficult, tailoring of interval imaging is acceptable.

3. Brain imaging
- Not routine for asymptomatic patients; obtain brain MRI if neurological symptoms or if clinically suspected metastasis. Consider baseline brain imaging in high-risk patients (e.g., stage III) per multidisciplinary discussion.

4. Laboratory tests and tumor markers
- Routine blood tests or tumor markers are not recommended for surveillance in asymptomatic patients except as clinically indicated.

5. Smoking cessation and preventive care
- Strong counseling and assistance for smoking cessation; offer pharmacotherapy and referral. Continue routine age-appropriate cancer screening and immunizations (influenza, pneumococcal, COVID-19 per local guidance).

6. Management of late effects and comorbidities
- Assess and manage treatment-related toxicities (pulmonary, cardiac, neuropathy), COPD and cardiovascular risk factors. Refer to pulmonary rehab, palliative care, or survivorship clinic as needed.

7. Survivorship and psychosocial care
- Offer symptom management, psychosocial support, nutritional counseling and rehabilitation. Discuss goals of care and advanced care planning when appropriate.

8. If systemic therapy (eg, targeted therapy, immunotherapy) is ongoing
- Follow toxicity monitoring and imaging frequency per the prescribing protocol/clinical trial guidelines (often imaging every 8–12 weeks initially), with modification based on response and toxicity.

9. Action on findings
- Prompt diagnostic workup (imaging, biopsy) for new or worsening symptoms or new radiographic findings to distinguish recurrence vs second primary vs benign changes.

Note: Specific intervals and modalities may vary by guideline (ASCO, NCCN, ESMO) and patient factors; individualize surveillance in multidisciplinary discussion.

Context assumed: patient with prior lung cancer (likely NSCLC) now with locoregional recurrence after 2 years. Management depends on recurrence site, performance status, prior treatments, pulmonary reserve, and histology. Below are concise, practical immediate therapeutic strategies for common scenarios you listed, with timing, how done, and alternatives.

1) Potential endobronchial obstruction (symptomatic hemoptysis, dyspnea, post-obstructive pneumonia)
- First-line: Bronchoscopic mechanical and thermal debulking ± stent placement
  - How/when: Urgent bronchoscopy (rigid or flexible with interventional capability) performed immediately or within 24–48 hours for airway compromise. Use mechanical debridement and thermal coagulation (electrocautery, Nd:YAG laser, argon plasma coagulation) to restore patency and control bleeding. If extrinsic compression or airway collapse remains, place a silicone or self‑expanding metallic airway stent.
  - Rationale: Rapid relief of obstruction and control of life‑threatening hemoptysis; provides tissue for diagnosis.
- Alternatives / if first-line not feasible:
  - Endobronchial brachytherapy (high-dose-rate): useful for endobronchial tumor control and hemoptysis when bronchoscopic debulking insufficient or tumor is diffusely infiltrative. Typically after stabilization; can be given within days.
  - External-beam palliative radiotherapy (short course, e.g., 20 Gy in 5 fx or 30 Gy in 10 fx): when bronchoscopy not available or patient unfit for procedures; effective for bleeding and tumor shrinkage—start as soon as stabilized.
  - Embolization of bronchial arteries: for severe hemoptysis not controlled bronchoscopically or radiotherapy‑refractory; performed by interventional radiology urgently.
  - Systemic therapy (chemo/targeted/immunotherapy): useful if tumor is chemosensitive and obstruction due to endoluminal disease but not as immediate relief; start after urgent airway control.

2) Resectable locoregional recurrence (isolated pulmonary/parenchymal or intrapulmonary nodule or bronchial recurrence amenable to surgery)
- First-line: Surgical resection (if prior treatment, consider feasibility)
  - How/when: Surgical evaluation urgently after staging (CT chest, PET-CT, mediastinal staging). If isolated resectable lesion and patient has adequate pulmonary reserve and comorbidity profile, perform metastectomy/segmentectomy/lobectomy or sleeve resection as appropriate. Timing: as soon as patient optimized—typically within weeks after workup.
  - Considerations: Prior thoracic surgery or prior radiation may complicate re‑operation; multidisciplinary board decision required.
- Alternatives / if surgery not indicated:
  - Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT)/stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR): excellent local control for small peripheral recurrences in patients unfit for or refusing surgery. Delivered over 1–5 fractions; arrange promptly after staging.
  - Thermal ablation (CT‑guided radiofrequency or microwave ablation): option for peripheral lesions <3–4 cm in high surgical-risk patients.
  - Concurrent chemoradiation: if resection not possible due to location or mediastinal involvement but patient fit, use curative-intent chemoradiation.
  - Systemic therapy: if recurrence is not truly isolated or molecular alterations guide targeted therapy/immunotherapy.

3) Mediastinal lymph node recurrence (isolated N2/N3 nodal recurrence)
- First-line: Salvage radiotherapy with or without chemotherapy
  - How/when: If isolated mediastinal nodal recurrence and prior thoracic RT dose allows, deliver radical-intent external beam radiotherapy (conformal or IMRT) to involved nodes. If prior RT given, consider re‑irradiation cautiously (dose constraints, hyperfractionation, proton therapy) and consult radiation oncology. Combine with platinum‑based chemotherapy (concurrent or sequential) if patient fit—start after staging and multidisciplinary planning; usually commence within 2–4 weeks of decision.
  - Rationale: High local control potential; chemo radiosensitizes.
- Alternatives / if prior RT prohibits or patient unfit:
  - Mediastinal surgical resection (mediastinoscopy/extended resection): rarely feasible; considered in highly selected patients after multidisciplinary review.
  - Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) or involved‑node hypofractionation: for limited nodal disease or re‑irradiation with careful planning.
  - Systemic therapy: If nodes are part of systemic recurrence or patient ineligible for local therapy, start systemic chemo, targeted therapy if actionable mutation, or immunotherapy as indicated.
  - Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS)–guided nodal cryo/laser debulking is not standard for mediastinal nodes but EBUS used for sampling.

General principles/appraisal
- Full restaging before definitive therapy: CT chest/abdomen, PET‑CT, and brain MRI to exclude distant disease; tissue confirmation of recurrence recommended when management would change.
- Multidisciplinary tumor board discussion essential (thoracic surgery, radiation oncology, medical oncology, pulmonology/interventional bronchoscopy, radiology).
- Consideration of prior treatments: prior surgery, chemotherapy, or thoracic radiotherapy limits options (especially re‑irradiation and repeat surgery).
- Palliative symptom control: for poor performance status, prioritize bronchoscopic palliation, short-course RT, embolization, and systemic therapy focused on symptom relief.

Main differentials to consider when NSCLC is the leading concern: metastatic cancer to the lung, small cell lung cancer (SCLC), primary pulmonary infections (esp. tuberculosis, fungal), benign pulmonary masses (granuloma, hamartoma), COPD-related changes/bronchiectasis with hemoptysis, pulmonary embolism, lymphoma (primary pulmonary or mediastinal), and non-neoplastic causes of cough/weight loss (heart failure, chronic infection, connective-tissue disease). Below I summarize how to distinguish each from NSCLC by key clinical features and targeted investigations.

1) Metastatic cancer to the lung
- Clinical clues: history of a known extrapulmonary malignancy (e.g., breast, colon, kidney, melanoma). Multiple nodules, systemic symptoms relating to primary tumor.
- Investigations: CT chest shows multiple, variable-sized pulmonary nodules often peripheral and subpleural; PET-CT may show uptake in lung lesions and primary site; tissue biopsy with histology/immunohistochemistry (IHC) to identify origin (e.g., TTF-1 typically lung; CK7/CK20 patterns). Searching for primary with CT abdomen/pelvis, mammography, colonoscopy as indicated.

2) Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
- Clinical clues: heavier smoking history, more rapid onset/progression, early systemic symptoms, paraneoplastic syndromes (SIADH, ectopic ACTH, Lambert-Eaton). Central tumors common.
- Investigations: Chest imaging often central mass with bulky mediastinal nodes; biopsy/cytology shows small cells, high mitotic index; distinct staging (limited vs extensive) and different management (chemoradiation vs surgery less common). Neuroendocrine markers (chromogranin, synaptophysin).

3) Pulmonary infections (tuberculosis, fungal, lung abscess)
- Clinical clues: fever, night sweats, purulent sputum, risk factors (exposure, immunosuppression), subacute–chronic course. TB can cause weight loss and hemoptysis.
- Investigations: Chest X-ray/CT may show cavitary lesion, consolidation, tree-in-bud for TB. Sputum AFB smear/culture, NAAT for Mycobacterium tuberculosis; fungal serology/culture, bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and biopsy if needed. PET can be falsely positive in infection.

4) Benign pulmonary nodules (granuloma, hamartoma)
- Clinical clues: often asymptomatic or mild symptoms; slow growth or stability on serial imaging. Hamartomas often incidental.
- Investigations: CT characteristics (calcification patterns, fat within hamartoma) suggest benignity. Compare prior imaging to assess growth rate (malignancy typically doubles in 1–6 months). PET may be variable; tissue diagnosis (CT-guided biopsy or surgical excision) if uncertain.

5) Bronchiectasis and COPD-related hemoptysis
- Clinical clues: chronic productive cough, history of recurrent infections, wheeze, longstanding COPD. Hemoptysis typically less massive.
- Investigations: High-resolution CT shows bronchial dilatation, bronchial wall thickening. Sputum culture, pulmonary function tests (spirometry) confirm COPD. Bronchoscopy to locate bleeding source and exclude endobronchial tumor.

6) Pulmonary embolism (PE)
- Clinical clues: sudden pleuritic chest pain, acute dyspnea, tachycardia, risk factors for venous thromboembolism; hemoptysis can occur but systemic weight loss and chronic cough are not typical.
- Investigations: D-dimer, CT pulmonary angiography to demonstrate filling defects. V/Q scan if CT contraindicated.

7) Primary pulmonary lymphoma or mediastinal lymphoma
- Clinical clues: B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), mediastinal mass or diffuse pulmonary infiltrates, sometimes less prominent smoking history.
- Investigations: CT chest shows mass or consolidative/nodular pattern; PET-CT shows uptake. Tissue diagnosis (core biopsy or excisional node biopsy) with lymphoid immunophenotyping.

8) Non-neoplastic systemic causes (cardiac failure, chronic infections, connective tissue disease)
- Clinical clues: orthopnea, edema (heart failure); systemic autoimmune features (arthralgia, rashes); chronic low-grade fever.
- Investigations: BNP, echocardiography for heart failure; autoimmune serology; targeted infectious workup.

Practical diagnostic approach to differentiate from NSCLC
- Detailed history and exam: smoking, prior malignancy, constitutional symptoms, risk exposures, paraneoplastic signs.
- Baseline imaging: chest radiograph then contrast-enhanced CT chest to characterize lesion (size, location, margins, cavitation, calcification, multiplicity, lymphadenopathy).
- Compare with prior imaging for growth.
- Laboratory tests: CBC, inflammatory markers, sputum studies (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), tumor markers rarely definitive.
- PET-CT: helps stage cancer and detect extrathoracic disease but can be false-positive with infection/inflammation.
- Tissue diagnosis: bronchoscopy with biopsy for central lesions, CT-guided percutaneous biopsy for peripheral nodules, or surgical (VATS) biopsy when needed. Histology + IHC distinguishes NSCLC vs SCLC vs metastasis vs lymphoma vs granulomatous disease.
- Pulmonary function tests: assess COPD severity and fitness for surgery.
- Additional targeted tests: BAL, AFB PCR for TB, fungal testing, echocardiography or CTA for PE if suspected.

Summary: Use clinical context and imaging to narrow differentials; definitive differentiation usually requires microbiology/cytology/histology (biopsy) and ancillary tests (PET, serology, cultures, immunostains).

Primary working diagnosis: progression of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) with possible prostatitis and concern for coexisting prostate malignancy (prostate cancer not excluded).

Justification:
- Longstanding lower urinary tract symptoms (slow stream, hesitancy, frequency, nocturia) over months are classic for BPH; he has a known BPH diagnosis.
- New lower pelvic discomfort and occasional gross or microscopic hematuria raise concern for superimposed prostatitis or other inflammatory/hemorrhagic change of the prostate.
- Intermittent hematuria and age >65 also warrant evaluation for prostate cancer and urinary tract malignancy (family history: father had prostate cancer at 74; uncle had bladder cancer).
- Lack of dysuria makes acute cystitis less likely; absence of systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, bone pain) makes metastatic prostate cancer less likely but does not exclude localized cancer.
- Additional evaluation needed: PSA, digital rectal exam, urinalysis/urine culture, and possibly imaging/urodynamic studies or referral to urology.

Significant risk factors from the history that support prostate cancer as the primary working diagnosis:
- Age: 65 years old (risk increases with age).
- Race: African American (higher incidence and mortality).
- Family history: father with prostate cancer (positive first-degree relative).
- Long interval without PSA screening: no PSA in 4 years (delayed detection).
- Lower urinary tract symptoms/BPH history: longstanding BPH may coexist and can mask/prolong diagnosis.

Less relevant or not significant for prostate cancer from this history: prior vasectomy (no consistent strong association), occasional hematuria (nonspecific), no weight loss/bone pain (no systemic signs).

Initial differential: worsening BPH vs prostatitis vs bladder pathology (urothelial cancer) vs prostate cancer. Immediate diagnostic workup to pursue, with reason and what each contributes:

1. Focused history and targeted physical exam
- Digital rectal exam (DRE): assess prostate size, symmetry, nodules, firmness — important to detect suspicious focal nodules or hard/irregular areas suggestive of prostate cancer vs smooth, enlarged prostate typical of BPH or diffuse tenderness of acute prostatitis.
- Vital signs: fever/HR to screen for acute infection.

2. Urinalysis with microscopy and urine culture
- Why: detect hematuria (gross or microscopic), pyuria or bacteriuria indicating urinary tract infection or prostatitis; hematuria raises concern for bladder cancer or other urothelial disease and guides need for cystoscopy/imaging. Culture guides antibiotics if infection suspected.

3. Serum prostate‑specific antigen (PSA) and PSA density if prostate volume obtained later
- Why: PSA helps screen for prostate cancer; values must be interpreted in context of BPH, prostatitis, recent DRE, catheterization, ejaculation, or recent prostate instrumentation (these can raise PSA). Baseline PSA is essential given family history and 4-year gap. PSA velocity/trend also useful.

4. Basic labs: CBC and serum creatinine (BMP)
- Why: CBC for leukocytosis (infection) or anemia; creatinine assesses renal function because chronic outlet obstruction can cause hydronephrosis/renal impairment and impacts imaging/contrast choices.

5. Postvoid residual (PVR) bladder ultrasound
- Why: quantify urinary retention from obstruction (BPH) and guide management (catheterization or surgery) and risk of upper tract injury.

6. Urine cytology (and urine-based molecular tests where available) if gross or persistent microscopic hematuria
- Why: evaluate for urothelial carcinoma of bladder/upper tract especially with hematuria and smoking history/family history.

7. Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) of prostate or transabdominal pelvic/renal ultrasound
- Why: TRUS estimates prostate volume (PSA density calculation), identifies focal lesions, and guides biopsy if indicated. Renal/bladder ultrasound assesses hydronephrosis, bladder lesions, and residual volume if PVR ultrasound unavailable.

8. If infection suspected: defer prostate biopsy/PSA interpretation until after treatment
- Why: prostatitis can raise PSA and biopsy during acute infection risks sepsis.

9. Cystoscopy (flexible) — indicated if hematuria persists or bladder cancer suspected
- Why: direct visualization of bladder mucosa to evaluate causes of gross hematuria (tumor, stone, inflammation) especially with age >35 and visible hematuria.

10. Multiparametric MRI (mpMRI) of prostate if PSA elevated and DRE abnormal or prior to biopsy
- Why: localize suspicious lesions, guide targeted biopsies, improve detection of clinically significant cancer and reduce detection of indolent disease.

11. Prostate biopsy (TRUS or MRI‑fusion guided) if mpMRI or clinical findings (PSA rise, abnormal DRE) suspicious
- Why: histologic diagnosis of prostate cancer; number of cores and targeted sampling based on imaging.

12. Urine culture, STI testing if relevant (e.g., NAAT for gonorrhea/chlamydia) — if younger or symptoms suggest urethritis
- Why: rule out sexually transmitted causes of hematuria/irritative symptoms when indicated.

Practical immediate sequence for this patient:
- DRE, vitals, UA + urine culture, CBC, creatinine, PSA (baseline), PVR bladder ultrasound or renal/bladder ultrasound.
- If UA shows infection → treat per culture and defer biopsy/interpret PSA repeat after treatment.
- If hematuria persists or UA negative but blood visible → refer for cystoscopy and upper tract imaging (CT urogram) to evaluate bladder/upper urinary tract.
- If PSA elevated or DRE abnormal → obtain mpMRI and urology referral for MRI‑fusion/transrectal biopsy as indicated.

Note: timing/interpretation of PSA should account for recent DRE, prostatitis, ejaculation, and prior vasectomy (vasectomy does not affect PSA).

Key assumptions: patient is high-risk prostate cancer (clinical T3a, PSA >20 ng/mL) with life expectancy >5 years. Management goals: confirm diagnosis, stage disease (local vs nodal vs distant), then offer definitive local therapy ± systemic therapy depending on extent. Below are recommended diagnostic and therapeutic steps with timing, how to perform them, and alternative approaches.

1) Confirm diagnosis with prostate biopsy (if not already done)
- How & when: Perform a systematic transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)- or transperineal-guided prostate biopsy with additional targeted cores if MRI lesion(s) are present. Do this promptly after elevated PSA or suspicious DRE and after discussing risks (bleeding, infection).
- Details: Standard is 12-core systematic sampling; add MRI-targeted fusion biopsies of PI-RADS ≥3 lesions to increase detection of clinically significant cancer.
- Alternatives: If prior biopsy positive and pathology adequate, repeat biopsy not required. In men unfit for biopsy, some centers will rely on MRI + clinical staging, but tissue diagnosis is preferred before definitive therapy.

2) Multiparametric prostate MRI (mpMRI)
- How & when: Obtain mpMRI of prostate (T2, diffusion, dynamic contrast) before biopsy or after initial positive biopsy to define local extent (extracapsular extension, seminal vesicle invasion) and to guide targeted cores. Do this early in staging workup.
- Alternative: If MRI contraindicated (eg, pacemaker) consider contrast-enhanced CT pelvis or rely on TRUS findings, recognizing lower sensitivity for extracapsular disease.

3) Cross-sectional imaging for nodal and distant staging
- How & when: For high-risk disease (cT3a or PSA >20), obtain imaging for nodal/metastatic disease prior to definitive local treatment.
  - Preferred modern approach: PSMA PET/CT (68Ga- or 18F-PSMA) — highest sensitivity/specificity to detect pelvic nodal and distant metastases; perform as initial staging when available.
  - If PSMA PET unavailable: Contrast-enhanced CT abdomen/pelvis plus bone scan (99mTc bone scintigraphy) to evaluate nodal and skeletal metastases.
- Timing: Before deciding on radical local therapy (surgery or radiotherapy) so findings can alter management (eg, detect metastatic disease that favors systemic therapy).
- Alternatives: Conventional imaging alone if PSMA PET not accessible.

4) Baseline labs and performance assessment
- How & when: CBC, CMP (renal/hepatic function), testosterone level, and baseline PSA (repeat to confirm), and assess performance status/comorbidities. Do pre-op evaluations if surgery planned.
- Alternatives: Add genomic or molecular risk tests (Decipher, Oncotype) on biopsy or prostatectomy tissue when available to refine prognosis — optional.

5) Multidisciplinary discussion and counseling
- How & when: Present case at tumor board (urology, radiation oncology, medical oncology, radiology, pathology) before definitive treatment to individualize therapy. Counsel patient on options, risks, and expected outcomes.

6) Definitive local therapy options (curative-intent) for localized/locally advanced high-risk disease (no distant metastases)
A) Radical prostatectomy (RP) with extended pelvic lymph node dissection (ePLND)
- How & when: Offer open/robotic radical prostatectomy with planned ePLND (extended template) in fit patients who desire removal of prostate and accurate nodal staging. Timing: within weeks-months after full staging workup and counseling.
- Rationale: RP offers local control and pathological staging; useful if patient prefers surgery or when local extension manageable.
- Adjuvant/Salvage: If adverse features (pT3, positive margins, nodal disease), consider adjuvant radiotherapy ± androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) or early salvage radiotherapy based on pathology and PSA kinetics.
- Alternatives: For patients unfit for surgery, proceed to radiation-based approach.

B) External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) + long-term androgen deprivation therapy (ADT)
- How & when: Conventionally fractionated or moderately hypofractionated EBRT to prostate ± seminal vesicles plus long-term ADT (typically 18–36 months) is standard for high-risk/locally advanced disease. Start ADT 1–3 months before radiotherapy (neoadjuvant) and continue during and after RT per protocol.
- Rationale: Combination improves survival vs RT alone in high-risk disease.
- Dose and field: Consider whole-pelvis radiotherapy if nodal risk high; boost to prostate with IMRT/VMAT. Use image guidance.
- Alternatives: Brachytherapy boost (low- or high-dose-rate) to prostate in combination with EBRT and ADT may be offered in select centers to escalate local dose for very high-risk disease, improving biochemical control but with higher toxicity.

C) Primary ADT alone
- How & when: Generally not curative for localized high-risk disease and reserved for patients unfit for definitive local therapy or with metastatic disease. Use LHRH agonist/antagonist ± antiandrogen.
- Alternatives: Intermittent ADT may be considered in some settings, but continuous ADT is standard with radiotherapy for high-risk disease.

7) If nodal or distant metastases identified
- Oligometastatic disease (limited nodes or bone metastases on PSMA PET)
  - How & when: Consider multimodal strategy: systemic therapy (ADT ± AR-targeted agent, e.g., abiraterone, enzalutamide) plus local therapy to prostate (RT) and metastasis-directed therapy (SBRT) in selected patients. Timing: initiate systemic therapy promptly; local treatments can be sequenced/combined per multidisciplinary plan.
- Widespread metastatic disease
  - How & when: Treat with systemic therapy: ADT plus androgen-receptor pathway inhibitors or chemotherapy (docetaxel) depending on volume and patient fitness. Local prostate therapy is generally palliative or considered in trials.
- Alternatives: Clinical trial enrollment for novel combinations, metastasis-directed management.

8) Pathology-driven adjuvant/salvage strategies after prostatectomy
- How & when: If adverse pathology (pT3, positive margins), discuss adjuvant radiotherapy vs early salvage radiotherapy with or without ADT. Decision based on margin status, PSA nadir/time to recurrence, and patient preference. Adjuvant RT typically within 3–4 months after surgery if chosen.
- Alternatives: Early salvage RT at first detectable PSA may avoid overtreatment.

9) Follow-up and surveillance
- How & when: After definitive therapy, monitor PSA every 3–6 months for first 2 years, then every 6–12 months. Assess for treatment side effects, manage ADT adverse effects, bone health, cardiovascular risk, and psychosocial support.
- Alternatives: Frequency tailored to recurrence risk and treatment.

Summary suggested pathway for this patient
1) Perform mpMRI and PSMA PET/CT (if available) promptly for local and systemic staging. 2) Obtain confirmatory prostate biopsy with MRI-targeted and systematic cores if biopsy not already performed. 3) Multidisciplinary review. 4) If no distant mets and patient is surgical candidate: offer radical prostatectomy with extended PLND OR definitive EBRT + long-term ADT (18–36 months); discuss brachytherapy boost as option. 5) If nodal/distant metastases: initiate systemic therapy (ADT ± AR-targeted agents/chemotherapy) and consider metastasis-directed therapy and local prostate RT per MDT discussion.

If the patient is low- to intermediate-risk and life expectancy <10 years:
- Active surveillance or conservative management (observation/watchful waiting) — prioritize symptom management and avoid definitive curative therapy; intervene only if symptoms progress or clinically indicated.
- Offer local symptom-directed treatments as needed (e.g., TURP for obstructive symptoms).
- Manage comorbidities and provide PSA monitoring at appropriate intervals if chosen.

If the patient is low- to intermediate-risk and life expectancy ≥10 years:
- Active surveillance is the preferred initial strategy for many low-risk and selected favorable intermediate-risk patients (regular PSA, DRE, repeat biopsies/MRI as indicated).
- Definitive curative treatment (radical prostatectomy or radiotherapy ± short-term androgen-deprivation therapy for unfavorable intermediate-risk) should be offered and discussed based on tumor features, patient preference, and functional considerations.
- Shared decision-making about risks/benefits, urinary/sexual function impact, and close follow-up are essential.

Recurrences after definitive treatment for prostate cancer are classified by location and timing:

- Biochemical (PSA) recurrence: rising PSA after surgery or radiation without clinical or radiographic evidence of disease.
  - After radical prostatectomy: detectable/rising PSA (commonly defined as ≥0.2 ng/mL on two occasions).
  - After radiation: rise of 2 ng/mL or more above nadir (Phoenix definition).

- Local (prostatic bed or residual prostate) recurrence: tumor confined to the prostate or surgical bed detected by imaging or biopsy.

- Regional recurrence: disease in regional lymph nodes (pelvic lymph nodes).

- Distant (metastatic) recurrence: spread to distant sites, most commonly bone, then lung, liver, or nonregional lymph nodes.

- Oligometastatic recurrence: limited number (often ≤3–5) of metastatic lesions amenable to metastasis-directed therapy.

Timing-wise, recurrences may be:
- Early biochemical recurrence (short PSA doubling time, higher risk of progression).
- Late/indolent biochemical recurrence (slow PSA rise, lower immediate risk).

Clinical implications depend on PSA kinetics (absolute level, doubling time), prior treatment, and imaging findings.

Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) — via surgical orchiectomy or medical castration (GnRH agonists/antagonists, antiandrogens) — causes multiple systemic effects. Common and important adverse effects include:

- Sexual dysfunction: decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, reduced orgasmic function
- Hot flashes and sweating
- Gynecomastia and breast tenderness
- Fatigue and decreased energy
- Loss of muscle mass and strength (sarcopenia)
- Increased body fat, weight gain (central adiposity)
- Bone loss → osteoporosis and increased fracture risk
- Metabolic changes: insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, new or worsened diabetes
- Adverse lipid changes: ↑ total cholesterol, LDL, triglycerides
- Increased cardiovascular risk: higher risk of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, stroke (especially in men with preexisting CV disease)
- Anemia (normocytic, normochromic)
- Cognitive and mood effects: memory problems, depression, mood lability
- Reduced physical function and quality of life
- Injection/site reactions (with depot formulations) and testosterone flare (with some GnRH agonists unless combined with antiandrogen)
- Rare: autoimmune or hepatotoxic effects with some antiandrogens

Risk magnitude varies with agent, duration of therapy, and patient comorbidities. Monitoring and preventive measures (bone density monitoring, cardiovascular risk management, glucose/lipid control, sexual health counseling) are recommended.

Main differentials to consider (with how to differentiate them from prostate cancer):

1. Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
- Clinical: Gradual onset of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in older men (hesitancy, weak stream, nocturia, incomplete emptying). Usually no systemic signs, typically smooth, enlarged, non‑nodular prostate on DRE.
- Investigations: PSA may be mildly to moderately elevated but less than typical cancer rises (PSA is not diagnostic alone). Urinalysis negative for infection or hematuria (unless concurrent). Transrectal ultrasound shows homogeneous gland enlargement. Uroflowmetry and post‑void residual (PVR) show obstructive pattern. Definitive distinction may need prostate biopsy if PSA/DRE suspicious.

2. Prostatitis (acute or chronic bacterial, chronic pelvic pain syndrome)
- Clinical: Acute bacterial prostatitis causes fever, chills, severe perineal/low back pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency; prostate tender, warm, boggy on DRE. Chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain has pelvic discomfort, variable LUTS, often younger.
- Investigations: Urinalysis/urine culture positive in bacterial prostatitis; elevated inflammatory markers. PSA can be transiently elevated. Symptom timeline (acute systemic illness) and prostate tenderness favor prostatitis over cancer.

3. Urethral stricture
- Clinical: History of prior instrumentation, trauma, STIs, or urethritis; symptoms include weak stream, spraying, hesitancy, post‑void dribbling; typically no systemic signs, normal prostate on DRE.
- Investigations: Retrograde urethrogram or cystoscopy demonstrates stricture; uroflowmetry shows obstructive flow pattern; PSA usually normal.

4. Bladder outlet obstruction from bladder stones or detrusor underactivity
- Clinical: Intermittent obstruction, suprapubic pain, hematuria (stones), or history of neurologic disease (detrusor underactivity). DRE often normal.

- Clinical: Painless gross or microscopic hematuria (most common), irritative voiding symptoms possible; risk factors include smoking, occupational exposures. DRE typically normal or nonspecific.
- Investigations: Urinalysis/urine cytology may show malignant cells; cystoscopy with biopsy is diagnostic. Imaging (CT urogram) to evaluate upper tracts.

- Clinical: Variable LUTS, urinary retention or incontinence, neurologic signs or history (diabetes, spinal disease). Prostate may be normal.

- Clinical: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, possible low‑grade fever; LUTS may mimic other causes. Prostate may be tender if prostatitis.
- Investigations: Urinalysis and urine culture confirm infection; symptoms improve with antibiotics.

Approach to differentiation in this patient
- Detailed history and focused exam: onset, systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, bone pain), risk factors (smoking, occupational exposures), prior instrumentation, neurologic disease; DRE for prostate size, consistency, nodules/fixation (nodularity or a hard irregular lobe favors cancer).
- Laboratory: Urinalysis and urine culture (rule out UTI/prostatitis/bladder pathology); PSA level (elevated PSA and PSA velocity raise suspicion for cancer but can be elevated in BPH, prostatitis, recent ejaculation, or instrumentation).
- Imaging and functional tests: Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) for prostate size and guided biopsy; multiparametric pelvic MRI (mpMRI) to localize suspicious lesions before biopsy; uroflowmetry and PVR for obstruction assessment; CT urogram and cystoscopy if hematuria or bladder cancer suspected.
- Microbiologic/other: Expressed prostatic secretions or 2‑glass/4‑glass test for chronic prostatitis if suspected.
- Definitive diagnosis: Prostate biopsy (TRUS or MRI‑targeted) for cancer. Cystoscopy with biopsy for bladder tumor. Urethrogram/cystoscopy for strictures.

In summary: use history/exam (DRE, systemic signs), urinalysis/urine culture, PSA trends, imaging (mpMRI/TRUS, CT urogram), functional testing (uroflow/PVR/urodynamics), and targeted endoscopy/biopsy to distinguish BPH, prostatitis, urethral/bladder causes, neurogenic causes, and bladder cancer from prostate cancer.

1. Focused history and physical exam (including rectal exam)
- Why: Clarify bleeding characteristics, systemic symptoms, risk factors, and look for mass, abdominal tenderness, hepatomegaly, cachexia, lymphadenopathy, or a palpable rectal mass.
- How: Detailed review of systems, medication review (anticoagulants), digital rectal exam (DRE) to detect distal lesions and assess for gross blood.

2. Complete blood count (CBC) with differential
- Why: Assess for iron-deficiency anemia from chronic blood loss and degree of anemia to guide urgency and transfusion need.
- How: Standard venous blood draw.

3. Basic metabolic panel (BMP) / comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
- Why: Evaluate renal function and electrolytes prior to imaging/contrast; baseline liver enzymes (CMP) help assess metastatic liver disease and operative risk.
- How: Venous blood test.

4. Liver function tests (LFTs) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
- Why: LFTs (AST, ALT, ALP, bilirubin) may suggest hepatic metastases. CEA is a tumor marker used for baseline staging and future surveillance if colorectal cancer is confirmed.
- How: Venous blood draw; note CEA is not diagnostic alone.

5. Coagulation profile (PT/INR, aPTT)
- Why: Important if invasive procedures (colonoscopy with biopsy) or if on anticoagulants; assesses bleeding risk.
- How: Venous blood test.

6. Stool studies: fecal occult blood test (if not already visibly bloody) and stool culture/C. difficile if diarrhea or infection suspected
- Why: Confirm GI bleeding and exclude infectious causes if diarrhea present. Occult blood is already suspected given visible blood.
- How: Stool sample collection per lab instructions.

7. Colonoscopy with targeted biopsy (urgent outpatient/expedited)
- Why: Gold standard to visualize the colon, identify lesion(s), biopsy for histopathologic diagnosis, and remove polyps if feasible. Essential to confirm colorectal cancer.
- How: Bowel preparation followed by colonoscopy performed by gastroenterologist; obtain multiple biopsies of any suspicious lesions. If obstruction suspected, do not force scope beyond obstructing lesion—obtain biopsies of accessible lesion and plan imaging.

8. Flexible sigmoidoscopy (only if full colonoscopy contraindicated or not immediately available)
- Why: Partial visualization of distal colon/rectum if full colonoscopy not possible; may detect distal tumors causing symptoms.
- How: Performed after limited bowel prep; biopsy any lesion.

9. Cross-sectional imaging: contrast-enhanced CT scan of chest, abdomen, and pelvis (CT CAP)
- Why: Staging—detect local invasion, regional lymphadenopathy, and distant metastases (especially liver and lungs). Important before definitive surgery planning.
- How: IV contrast-enhanced CT from chest through pelvis; if renal impairment, consider noncontrast or alternative imaging.

10. MRI pelvis (for rectal tumors or if rectal cancer suspected)
- Why: Superior local staging of rectal cancer (mesorectal fascia involvement, sphincter/anal sphincter complex) to plan neoadjuvant therapy.
- How: Pelvic MRI with high-resolution rectal protocol; endorectal ultrasound is an alternative for T staging if available.

11. CT chest (if not included in CT CAP) or chest CT as part of staging
- Why: Lung metastases are common; include chest imaging in staging.
- How: As above (often performed as part of CT CAP).

12. Liver imaging (if CT equivocal): dedicated liver MRI with contrast or contrast-enhanced ultrasound
- Why: Better characterization of hepatic lesions seen on CT; important for resectability decisions.
- How: MRI liver with hepatocyte-specific contrast agent.

13. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) for rectal lesions (if available)
- Why: Accurate T and N staging for rectal cancer when MRI is inconclusive; guides neoadjuvant therapy decisions.
- How: Performed by trained endosonographer; EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration if suspicious nodes.

14. Biopsy pathology with immunohistochemistry (IHC) and molecular testing (after tissue obtained)
- Why: Confirm histologic diagnosis, differentiate adenocarcinoma subtypes, and perform molecular profiling (KRAS/NRAS/BRAF, MSI/MMR) to guide systemic therapy and immunotherapy decisions.
- How: Formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue from colonoscopic biopsy or surgical specimen; order reflex testing for MMR/MSI and oncogenic mutations per guidelines.

15. Baseline ECG and cardiopulmonary assessment as preoperative evaluation (if surgery likely)
- Why: Assess perioperative risk given age, smoking history and possible comorbidities.
- How: Resting ECG and targeted cardiopulmonary evaluation based on history/exam.

16. Nutrition assessment and baseline performance status evaluation
- Why: Weight loss and fatigue affect treatment tolerance; optimize nutrition pre-treatment.
- How: Dietitian consult, weight/BMI, labs (albumin), performance scoring (ECOG).

- Urgent: history/physical, DRE, CBC, CMP/LFTs, coagulation, CEA, and colonoscopy with biopsy are immediate priorities to confirm diagnosis.
- Staging imaging (CT CAP, MRI pelvis) should follow prompt tissue diagnosis to plan therapy.
- Molecular testing is done on biopsy tissue once malignancy confirmed.

If obstruction, perforation, or significant hemorrhage is suspected, obtain emergent imaging (abdominal CT) and consult surgery/gastroenterology immediately rather than bowel preparation for colonoscopy.

  - How/when: Begin systemic adjuvant chemotherapy within ~6–8 weeks post-op (when recovered).   - Neoadjuvant (preoperative) chemoradiotherapy (CRT) or short-course radiotherapy followed by surgery.
  - How/when:
    - Long-course CRT: Concurrent pelvic radiotherapy (45–50.4 Gy in 25–28 fractions) with concurrent 5-FU–based chemo (capecitabine or infusional 5-FU), then total mesorectal excision (TME) 6–12 weeks after completion to allow maximal tumor regression.
    - Short-course RT: 5 x 5 Gy over one week, then immediate surgery or delayed surgery (~4–8 weeks); often used where downstaging is less critical.
  - Rationale: Neoadjuvant RT/CRT reduces local recurrence, can downstage tumor, increase sphincter preservation, and improves resectability.
- Surgery:
  - How/when: Total mesorectal excision (TME) with appropriate distal margin and regional lymphadenectomy, performed after neoadjuvant therapy (typical interval as above). Low anterior resection or abdominoperineal resection depending on tumor location and sphincter involvement.
- Adjuvant chemotherapy:
  - How/when: Postoperative systemic chemotherapy (commonly FOLFOX or CAPOX for ~6 months) is recommended, particularly for node-positive disease, started when patient recovered from surgery (typically within 6–8 weeks).
