- Alternatives if first-line therapies not indicated:

Summary of NCCN recommendations for molecular testing in colorectal carcinoma (latest guidance):

1) Universal Mismatch Repair (MMR)/Microsatellite Instability (MSI) testing
- Test all new colorectal cancers for MMR deficiency (by IHC for MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2) and/or MSI (PCR or NGS-based MSI).
- Abnormal MMR/MSI results should prompt reflex testing for MLH1 promoter methylation and/or BRAF V600E (to help distinguish sporadic MLH1 loss from Lynch syndrome).
- If MLH1 promoter methylation or BRAF V600E is negative with MLH1 loss, refer for germline testing for Lynch syndrome (genetic counseling).

2) Somatic tumor genomic profiling (recommended for most stage II–IV and selected high-risk stage I)
- Broad-panel NGS (comprehensive somatic profiling) is recommended to identify actionable alterations and guide targeted therapies and immunotherapy decisions.
- Core genes/biomarkers to report/include: RAS (KRAS and NRAS codons 12, 13, 61, and other recommended codons), BRAF (V600 and non-V600 as indicated), HER2 (ERBB2) alterations, NTRK fusions, MSI/MMR status, tumor mutational burden (TMB) when available, and POLE mutations (ultramutated phenotype).
- For anti-EGFR therapy decisions, document extended RAS (KRAS/NRAS) and BRAF status.

3) Specific actionable biomarkers to test and therapeutic implications
- RAS (KRAS/NRAS) mutations: test all metastatic CRC before anti-EGFR therapy; presence predicts lack of benefit from anti-EGFR antibodies.
- BRAF V600E: test in metastatic disease (prognostic and predictive; guides BRAF-targeted regimens).
- HER2 (ERBB2) amplification/overexpression: test in RAS/BRAF WT metastatic CRC for potential anti-HER2 therapy.
- NTRK fusions: test (or include in panel) in metastatic disease — NTRK fusion-positive tumors may benefit from TRK inhibitors.
- MSI-H/dMMR: test for immunotherapy eligibility (pembrolizumab, dostarlimab, etc.) in advanced disease.
- POLE exonuclease domain mutations: identify ultramutated tumors which may respond to immunotherapy.

4) Use of tissue vs. plasma
- Tissue-based testing preferred for initial comprehensive profiling. Plasma (circulating tumor DNA) testing is acceptable when tissue unavailable or to assess resistance mechanisms; negative plasma should be followed by tissue testing if clinical suspicion remains.

5) Timing and reporting
- Perform testing at diagnosis of advanced/metastatic disease or earlier when results would impact adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy decisions.
- Reports should state methodology, sensitivity, coverage, variants classified per standards, and clinical interpretation/actionability.

6) Germline testing considerations
- Patients with dMMR/MSI-H without MLH1 methylation or BRAF V600E, and patients meeting hereditary cancer criteria, should be offered germline testing for Lynch syndrome.
- Consider germline testing for other hereditary syndromes based on family history and tumor findings.

Note: NCCN guidelines are periodically updated. For patient care, consult the current NCCN Colorectal Cancer guideline document on NCCN.org for full details, recommended gene panels, exact codons to be examined, and therapeutic algorithms.

Recommendations below reflect commonly used guideline frameworks (NCCN, ASCO, ESMO) — adapt timing/frequency to tumor stage, patient fitness, and local practice.

1) Clinical follow-up
- History and physical exam every 3–6 months for the first 2 years, then every 6 months up to year 5, then annually as indicated.
- Assess symptoms, weight, performance status, and treatment toxicities.

2) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
- Serum CEA every 3–6 months for the first 2 years, then every 6 months to year 5 (total ~5 years), if CEA was elevated at diagnosis and patient is a candidate for further curative therapy. Interpret rises in context; investigate persistent rise.

3) Cross-sectional imaging
- CT chest/abdomen/pelvis with contrast (or chest CT + abdominal/pelvic CT) every 6–12 months for the first 2–3 years, then as clinically indicated up to 5 years. Typical practice: CT annually or every 6–12 months for first 3 years for stage II/III; more intensive for higher risk.

4) Colonoscopic surveillance
- Complete colonoscopy at 1 year after resection (or sooner if preoperative colonoscopy incomplete). If normal, repeat at 3 years, then at 5 years, then every 5 years thereafter (intervals adjusted for adenomas, synchronous lesions, or hereditary risk). If polyps are found, follow polypectomy surveillance intervals per polyp pathology.

5) Additional testing as indicated
- Consider CEA-directed or symptom-directed earlier imaging (PET/CT) when recurrence suspected.
- If rectal cancer or locally advanced disease, pelvic MRI or endorectal ultrasound and multidisciplinary follow-up as appropriate.

6) Survivorship care
- Manage chemotherapy/ radiation late effects, psychosocial support, lifestyle counseling (smoking cessation, physical activity, diet), and vaccination/ preventive care.
- Genetic counseling and germline testing if family history or young age suggests hereditary syndromes.

7) Duration
- Routine surveillance generally for 5 years; some elements (colonoscopic surveillance, survivorship care) may continue beyond based on findings and risk.

Provide a concise list of the main differential diagnoses for an older adult with change in bowel habits, intermittent rectal bleeding, weight loss, fatigue and lower abdominal discomfort, then for each explain key distinguishing clinical features and which investigations would help differentiate it from colon carcinoma.

1) Colorectal adenomatous polyp (large/villous)
- Clinical: Often asymptomatic or can cause occult bleeding and iron-deficiency anemia. Symptoms less likely to include weight loss, systemic features, or obstructive symptoms unless large.
- Investigations: Colonoscopy with polypectomy and histology is diagnostic; imaging not necessary if colonoscopy visualizes lesion. Biopsy differentiates benign adenoma vs invasive carcinoma.

2) Inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease)
- Clinical: Usually younger onset but can present at older age. Chronic diarrhea, urgency, tenesmus, mucous/bloody stools, abdominal pain; systemic flares, extraintestinal manifestations. History often longer than a few months and may have prior episodes.
- Investigations: Colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal inflammation in ulcerative colitis or segmental/transmural lesions with skip lesions, cobblestoning, and strictures in Crohn’s. Biopsies show chronic inflammatory changes (crypt abscesses, granulomas in Crohn’s). Fecal calprotectin and inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR) support IBD over malignancy.

3) Ischemic colitis
- Clinical: Usually acute onset crampy abdominal pain followed by bloody diarrhea in older patients with vascular disease; pain often out of proportion early. Typically more sudden than cancer.
- Investigations: CT abdomen may show segmental bowel wall thickening; colonoscopy reveals segmental mucosal changes with sharp transition and biopsy shows mucosal and submucosal ischemic injury. Clinical context (hypotension, atherosclerosis) helps differentiate.

4) Infectious colitis (bacterial, parasitic)
- Clinical: Acute onset of diarrhea (often watery or bloody), fever, recent travel, food exposure or antibiotic use; systemic toxicity more common acutely than with cancer.
- Investigations: Stool studies (culture, C. difficile toxin, ova & parasites, PCR panels) identify pathogens. Colonoscopy/biopsy rarely needed unless severe or persistent.

5) Diverticular disease (diverticulitis or bleeding)
- Clinical: Left lower quadrant pain, fever, leukocytosis for diverticulitis; painless bright rectal bleeding for diverticular hemorrhage in older patients. Diverticular bleeding is often brisk but intermittent, unlike occult bleeding from cancer.
- Investigations: CT abdomen with contrast is diagnostic for diverticulitis (pericolic fat stranding, inflamed diverticula). Colonoscopy is deferred acutely but used later to rule out malignancy. Angiography or tagged RBC scan for active bleeding.

6) Hemorrhoids/Anal fissure
- Clinical: Bright red blood on toilet paper or coating stool, minimal systemic symptoms, no weight loss or change in stool caliber. Pain (especially with fissure) at defecation.
- Investigations: Anoscopy or proctoscopy confirms hemorrhoids/fissure. Colonoscopy indicated if red flags (weight loss, anemia, altered bowel habit, age >50) to exclude proximal pathology.

7) Gastrointestinal lymphoma
- Clinical: Can present with abdominal pain, weight loss, bleeding, systemic “B” symptoms (fever, night sweats). More rapid course sometimes; may have palpable mass.
- Investigations: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for masses, endoscopic biopsy with histology/immunophenotyping distinguishes lymphoma from adenocarcinoma.

8) Metastatic cancer to colon (e.g., ovarian, gastric) or secondary malignancies
- Clinical: May have primary-site symptoms or signs; multiple lesions on imaging; history of other primary cancer.
- Investigations: Cross-sectional imaging (CT/PET), colonoscopy with biopsy and immunohistochemistry to identify origin.

9) Irritable bowel syndrome (less likely)
- Clinical: Chronic recurrent abdominal pain related to defecation with change in stool form/frequency, but absence of alarm features (weight loss, bleeding, anemia). IBS does not cause rectal bleeding or progressive symptoms.
- Investigations: Diagnosis of exclusion. Basic labs (CBC, CRP), stool tests, and colonoscopy if alarm features present (which in this case they are), to exclude organic disease.

10) Radiation proctitis (if history of pelvic radiation)
- Clinical: Rectal bleeding, tenesmus, urgency in patient with prior pelvic radiation; symptoms and timing linked to treatment.
- Investigations: Endoscopy shows telangiectasias and friable mucosa; biopsy avoids deep sampling.

Key investigation strategy to differentiate from colon carcinoma
- CBC (look for iron-deficiency anemia), chemistry, CRP/ESR. Anemia and occult blood make carcinoma more likely.
- Fecal calprotectin and stool studies if infection or IBD suspected.
- Colonoscopy with visualization and biopsy is the gold standard to distinguish adenocarcinoma from most other causes. Any suspicious mass requires biopsy and histopathology.
- CT scan of abdomen/pelvis (with contrast) for staging if cancer suspected; also helps identify diverticulitis, ischemia, large inflammatory masses or extraluminal disease.
- Flexible sigmoidoscopy/anoscopic exam for distal sources (hemorrhoids, fissure).
- Endoscopic biopsy with immunohistochemistry, and if lymphoma suspected, flow cytometry and appropriate markers.
- Angiography/tagged RBC scan for active brisk bleeding of uncertain source.

Red flags that should prompt urgent evaluation for colon carcinoma
- Age >50 (or <50 with risk factors), unexplained iron-deficiency anemia, persistent change in bowel habits, rectal bleeding, unintentional weight loss, family history of colorectal cancer.

Summary: Clinical context and tempo (acute vs chronic), systemic features, stool and blood tests guide initial differentiation, but colonoscopy with targeted biopsy is the definitive test to confirm or exclude colon carcinoma and to distinguish most alternatives.

Most likely diagnosis: renal cell carcinoma (RCC) given painless gross hematuria, constitutional B symptoms, smoking, older male. To confirm and stage RCC and exclude other causes of hematuria, perform the following tests — with rationale and how each is done:

1. Urinalysis with microscopy
- Why: confirm hematuria, detect dysmorphic RBCs vs. intact RBCs (renal vs. lower tract), look for pyuria/ infection, proteinuria.
- How: midstream clean-catch urine; dipstick and microscopic exam for RBCs, WBCs, casts.

2. Urine culture
- Why: exclude urinary tract infection as cause of hematuria/fever.
- How: midstream or catheterized specimen plated for bacteria.

3. Urine cytology (and urine tumor markers if available)
- Why: detect malignant urothelial cells to evaluate for urothelial carcinoma of renal pelvis/bladder (differential for painless hematuria).
- How: send fresh voided urine samples for cytologic exam; repeat samples increase yield.

4. Blood tests: CBC, CMP (including creatinine, BUN, electrolytes, liver function tests), coagulation studies, ESR/CRP
- Why: CBC for anemia (chronic blood loss, paraneoplastic), CMP for renal function (impacts imaging/contrast choice) and liver mets, coagulation prior to interventions, ESR/CRP for inflammatory state.
- How: standard venous blood draw.

5. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of abdomen and pelvis — CT urogram with multiphasic renal protocol (non-contrast, corticomedullary, nephrographic, excretory phases)
- Why: gold-standard imaging to detect renal masses, characterize size/location, enhancement pattern (solid enhancing mass favors RCC vs. cyst), assess collecting system, local invasion, lymph nodes, and evaluate contralateral kidney and ureters.
- How: IV iodinated contrast unless contraindicated (check creatinine); multiphase CT renal protocol.

6. If CT contraindicated (eg, contrast allergy or impaired renal function): MRI abdomen with gadolinium-free or appropriate protocol (multiparametric MRI) or contrast MRI if renal function allows
- Why: alternative to CT to characterize renal lesion and evaluate IVC/vena caval thrombus and local invasion.
- How: MRI with and without contrast; MR venography if IVC involvement suspected.

7. Chest imaging: CT chest with contrast (or at minimum chest CT without contrast)
- Why: evaluate for pulmonary metastases (most common metastatic site) and thoracic lymphadenopathy.
- How: CT chest.

8. Renal ultrasound (adjunct)
- Why: quick, noninvasive initial test to distinguish cystic vs. solid mass; useful in patients who cannot have CT/MRI; can detect hydronephrosis.
- How: abdominal ultrasound targeted to kidneys; Doppler if vascular assessment needed.

9. Cystoscopy (and possible bladder biopsy)
- Why: evaluate bladder and urethra for urothelial carcinoma as source of hematuria; indicated when hematuria could be lower tract or when urine cytology positive for urothelial malignancy.
- How: outpatient cystoscopic exam with direct visualization and biopsy of suspicious lesions.

10. Percutaneous renal mass biopsy (core biopsy)
- Why: not always required for classic radiographic RCC prior to nephrectomy, but indicated when imaging is inconclusive, when considering active surveillance, ablative therapy, systemic therapy, or in metastatic disease to obtain histology/subtype and guide systemic treatment.
- How: CT- or ultrasound-guided percutaneous core needle biopsy of the renal lesion; send for histology, immunohistochemistry, and molecular testing as indicated.

11. Doppler ultrasound or MRI venography of IVC
- Why: assess for renal vein or inferior vena cava tumor thrombus extension (important for surgical planning).
- How: Doppler ultrasound can screen; CT/MRI with venous phase more accurate.

12. Staging labs for metastatic disease if confirmed: LDH, calcium, albumin, thyroid function as clinically indicated
- Why: RCC can cause paraneoplastic hypercalcemia, altered LFTs; LDH may reflect tumor burden; baseline labs guide prognosis and therapy.
- How: standard blood draws.

13. Baseline ECG and preoperative assessment
- Why: evaluate fitness for surgery (nephrectomy) given age and comorbidities.
- How: ECG, cardiology consult as indicated.

Summary prioritized approach:
- Initial: urinalysis, urine culture/cytology, CBC/CMP, renal ultrasound or CT urogram (CT renal multiphase preferred).
- If CT shows suspicious enhancing solid renal mass: obtain CT chest for staging, consider percutaneous biopsy if needed for treatment planning, evaluate for venous thrombus (CT/MRI), and proceed with multidisciplinary staging and surgical planning.

Therapeutic strategy for kidney cancer (renal cell carcinoma, RCC) depends on stage, histology, patient fitness and goals (curative vs palliative). Key options and when to use them:

1. Localized disease (clinical stage I–II; tumor confined to kidney)
- Partial nephrectomy (nephron‑sparing surgery): preferred for T1a (≤4 cm) and whenever technically feasible for T1b (4–7 cm) or solitary kidney/compromised renal function. Offers oncologic control with renal function preservation.
- Radical nephrectomy: indicated for larger tumors (T2 and many T1b depending on location/complexity), central/hilar tumors, multifocal disease not amenable to partial nephrectomy, or when partial would be unsafe.
- Minimally invasive approaches (laparoscopic/robotic) when available and appropriate.
- Ablative therapies (percutaneous radiofrequency ablation or cryoablation): option for small tumors (generally ≤3–4 cm) in poor surgical candidates or patients who decline surgery.
- Active surveillance: reasonable for small renal masses (especially elderly/comorbid or tumors <2–3 cm) with periodic imaging.

2. Locally advanced disease (T3–T4, regional lymph node involvement)
- Radical nephrectomy with thrombectomy if tumor extends into renal vein/inferior vena cava and patient is surgical candidate — can be curative for nonmetastatic locally advanced disease.
- Lymph node dissection: limited to clinically positive nodes (therapeutic, not routinely for all).
- Consider neoadjuvant systemic therapy or embolization only in select trials or to downstage in unresectable cases (not standard).

3. Metastatic disease (stage IV)
- Cytoreductive (debulking) nephrectomy: was historically performed before systemic therapy in fit patients with good performance status and limited comorbidity; current approach is selective — consider when removal of primary tumor is likely to improve symptoms or response to systemic therapy. For many patients, start systemic therapy first; evaluate need for nephrectomy case-by-case.
- Systemic therapy (first-line for most metastatic clear cell RCC):
  - Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI)-based combinations (now standard for many): e.g., pembrolizumab + axitinib, nivolumab + ipilimumab (particularly for intermediate/poor risk), or other approved ICI + VEGF TKI combos depending on risk group and comorbidities.
  - VEGF tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) (sunitinib, pazopanib, cabozantinib) used when ICI combinations contraindicated or in subsequent lines.
  - mTOR inhibitors (everolimus) in later lines or non‑clear cell subtypes in select situations.
- Metastasectomy or stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR): consider for limited oligometastatic disease if complete resection/ablation feasible and patient likely to benefit.
- Palliative radiation for symptomatic metastases (bone, brain) and supportive care.

4. Non‑clear cell RCC
- Management differs; many non‑clear histologies respond less well to standard clear‑cell regimens. Options include clinical trials, targeted agents (TKIs), or ICIs based on subtype and guideline recommendations.

5. Follow‑up and surveillance
- Imaging schedule depends on initial stage and treatment; higher stage = more frequent surveillance for recurrence/metastasis.

Key determinants of choice
- Stage (localized vs locally advanced vs metastatic)
- Histologic subtype (clear cell vs non‑clear)
- Tumor size/location and renal function (influence partial vs radical nephrectomy)
- Patient comorbidities, life expectancy, performance status
- Prognostic risk (e.g., IMDC/Motzer criteria) for systemic therapy selection

Refer to current national guidelines (NCCN/ESMO) and multidisciplinary tumor board for individualized therapy and sequencing.

Possible complications of kidney cancer (renal cell carcinoma, RCC) and management

1. Local extension and compression
- Complications: Hematuria from invasion of collecting system; flank pain; palpable mass; urinary obstruction/hydronephrosis from ureteral or renal pelvis involvement; invasion of adjacent organs (adrenal gland, colon, pancreas).
- Management: Surgical resection (partial or radical nephrectomy) to relieve mass effect; stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy for obstruction; pain control; targeted systemic therapy if unresectable.

2. Vascular invasion and thrombus
- Complications: Tumor thrombus in renal vein and inferior vena cava (IVC) causing venous congestion, lower extremity edema, risk of pulmonary embolism.
- Management: Surgical thrombectomy with radical nephrectomy (often with cardiothoracic/vascular team for high IVC thrombi); perioperative anticoagulation typically withheld until surgical removal; if surgery contraindicated, systemic therapy and anticoagulation as appropriate.

3. Metastatic disease
- Complications: Spread to lungs, bone, liver, brain causing respiratory symptoms, bone pain/fractures, hepatic dysfunction, neurological deficits.
- Management: Stage-directed therapy — metastasectomy when feasible, systemic immunotherapy (checkpoint inhibitors), targeted therapies (VEGF tyrosine kinase inhibitors, mTOR inhibitors), stereotactic radiation for brain mets, palliative radiotherapy for bone pain, bisphosphonates/denosumab for skeletal events.

4. Paraneoplastic syndromes
- Complications: Erythrocytosis (polycythemia) from ectopic EPO → hyperviscosity; hypercalcemia from PTHrP production; nonmetastatic hepatopathy (Stauffer syndrome) with abnormal LFTs; hypertension; cachexia; coagulopathy.
- Management: Treat underlying tumor (nephrectomy or systemic therapy) often reverses paraneoplastic effects; for symptomatic control: phlebotomy or hydroxyurea for severe erythrocytosis, IV fluids/bisphosphonates/denosumab and calcitonin for hypercalcemia, supportive care for hepatic dysfunction, manage hypertension per guidelines.

5. Postoperative complications (after partial or radical nephrectomy)
- Complications: Acute kidney injury (AKI) and reduced renal function (risk of chronic kidney disease), bleeding/hemorrhage, wound infection, urine leak/urinoma, venous thromboembolism.
- Management: Perioperative optimization of renal function (avoid nephrotoxins, ensure volume status), partial nephrectomy when feasible to preserve nephrons; monitor creatinine, urine output; manage bleeding with transfusion/angiographic embolization or reoperation if needed; antibiotics and wound care for infection; drainage for urine leak; prophylaxis and treatment of VTE with anticoagulation when safe.

6. Treatment-related toxicities (systemic therapy)
- Complications: Immune-related adverse events from checkpoint inhibitors (colitis, pneumonitis, hepatitis, endocrinopathies); hypertension, hand–foot syndrome, proteinuria, hemorrhage or thrombotic events from VEGF-targeted TKIs; metabolic effects from mTOR inhibitors.
- Management: For immune toxicities — hold therapy and give corticosteroids or other immunosuppressants per severity and guidelines, endocrine replacement if needed; for VEGF-TKI toxicities — dose modification, supportive care (antihypertensives, manage proteinuria, dermatologic care), switch agents if intolerable; monitor labs regularly.

7. Psychological and functional complications
- Complications: Depression, reduced quality of life, impaired functional status.
- Management: Psychosocial support, cancer rehabilitation, pain control, referral to counseling/palliative care.

Brief practical approach
- Early-stage RCC: surgical resection (partial nephrectomy preferred if feasible) to treat tumor and often resolves many paraneoplastic syndromes.
- Locally advanced/metastatic disease: multimodal — surgery when appropriate, systemic immunotherapy/targeted therapy, radiotherapy for palliation.
- Manage complications expectantly: address acute issues (bleeding, obstruction, thrombus, hypercalcemia), monitor and mitigate renal function loss, and treat therapy-related toxicities per established oncology guidelines.

Main differentials for a 65‑year‑old male with painless gross hematuria, constitutional symptoms and risk factors (smoking, HTN, obesity) include:
- Urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma of the bladder or renal pelvis
- Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) with prostatic bleeding / prostate cancer
- Urinary tract infection / prostatitis (less likely if painless)
- Nephrolithiasis
- Glomerular disease (e.g., IgA nephropathy, RPGN)
- Renal infarct / vascular disease
- Trauma
- Coagulopathy / anticoagulant use
- Metastatic cancer to kidney from another primary
For each, how to differentiate clinically and with investigations vs renal cell carcinoma (RCC):

1) Urothelial carcinoma (bladder or renal pelvis)
- Clinical: Painless gross hematuria common; may have irritative voiding (frequency, urgency, dysuria) if bladder involved. Smoking is a strong risk factor.
- Investigations: Urine cytology often positive for malignant urothelial cells. Cystoscopy with direct visualization and biopsy is diagnostic for bladder lesions. CT urogram will show urothelial lesions lining collecting system/ureter/bladder rather than solid enhancing renal parenchymal mass typical for RCC. Urine-based markers sometimes helpful. Ureteroscopy/retrograde pyelography can evaluate upper tract.

2) Prostate causes (BPH/prostate cancer)
- Clinical: BPH gives obstructive/irritative LUTS; hematuria usually microscopic; prostate cancer may be asymptomatic or cause back pain (mets). Hematuria less commonly gross and often with urinary symptoms.
- Investigations: Digital rectal exam, PSA level. Urine dip/urinalysis and culture. Transrectal ultrasound / prostate MRI and biopsy if PSA/DRE suspicious. Imaging for RCC typically shows a renal mass on ultrasound/CT not explained by prostate disease.

3) Urinary tract infection / prostatitis
- Clinical: Usually dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain, fever; gross hematuria possible but usually painful. Constitutional symptoms can occur with systemic infection.
- Investigations: Urinalysis with pyuria, positive urine culture. Hematuria from infection usually resolves with treatment. CT/ultrasound will not show solid renal tumor.

4) Nephrolithiasis
- Clinical: Severe colicky flank pain radiating to groin, visible hematuria; usually painful unlike painless RCC. May have history of stones.
- Investigations: Noncontrast CT KUB is diagnostic for stones. Urinalysis shows RBCs but no malignant cells. Imaging for RCC shows enhancing solid mass; stones are radiopaque on CT without enhancement.

5) Glomerular disease (eg IgA nephropathy, RPGN)
- Clinical: Often microscopic hematuria, sometimes gross, often with proteinuria, edema, hypertension; can have RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs. Systemic signs depend on etiology.
- Investigations: Urinalysis shows dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, proteinuria. Serologic tests (ANA, ANCA, complement, anti-GBM) as indicated. Renal biopsy diagnostic. Imaging for RCC would show mass; glomerular disease shows normal renal imaging.

6) Renal infarct / vascular causes
- Clinical: Acute flank pain, fever, sometimes hematuria; risk factors for embolism (AF) or vascular disease.
- Investigations: CT angiography or contrast CT shows wedge‑shaped perfusion defect; labs show elevated LDH. Not a focal enhancing mass.

7) Trauma / coagulopathy / anticoagulant use
- Clinical: History of trauma or anticoagulants; bleeding may be more diffuse; painless hematuria possible.
- Investigations: Medication history, coagulation studies (INR, aPTT), CT/ultrasound if trauma suspected. No enhancing renal mass.

8) Metastatic disease to kidney or other primary (e.g., pelvic malignancy)
- Clinical: History or symptoms referable to another primary (lung, colon, etc.). Constitutional symptoms common.
- Investigations: Cross-sectional imaging (CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, PET) to identify primary and pattern. Biopsy of renal lesion distinguishes primary RCC (clear cell, papillary, chromophobe histology) from metastasis (histology, immunostains).

Key investigations to distinguish RCC from others
- Urinalysis with microscopy and urine cytology: dysmorphic RBCs/RBC casts suggest glomerular source; malignant cells suggest urothelial tumor.
- Urine culture: excludes UTI.
- PSA, DRE: evaluate prostate causes.
- Imaging:
  - Ultrasound: initial to detect renal mass vs stone or hydronephrosis.
  - CT urogram with contrast (triple-phase abdominal CT) — best for RCC: shows an enhancing solid renal mass with characteristic arterial enhancement; differentiates from urothelial carcinoma (filling defects in collecting system) and stones or infarcts.
  - Noncontrast CT for stones.
  - Cystoscopy: required to evaluate bladder/ureteral urothelial carcinoma if hematuria unexplained or urine cytology positive.
- Renal biopsy: percutaneous core biopsy when imaging indeterminate or to confirm metastasis vs RCC before systemic therapy.
- Laboratory tests: CBC, renal function, coagulation, inflammatory markers; serology for glomerular disease if suspected.
- Further staging: chest CT for lung mets, bone scan if bone pain.

Practical approach
- Urinalysis + urine culture + urine cytology and PSA/DRE.
- Imaging: CT urogram (or contrast abdominal CT) to evaluate kidneys and collecting system; noncontrast CT if stones suspected.
- Cystoscopy if CT negative for renal mass or to evaluate bladder/urothelial malignancy.
- Renal biopsy if imaging indeterminate or needed to guide treatment.

This strategy distinguishes RCC (contrast‑enhancing renal parenchymal mass, histology on biopsy/excision) from urothelial tumors (positive urine cytology, cystoscopic/pyelographic lesions), prostatic/UTI/stone/glomerular and vascular causes by combining clinical features, lab tests, targeted imaging, cystoscopy and selective biopsy.

- Why: Baseline for anemia (affects cardiac ischemia risk), infection, or bleeding risk if interventions needed.

  - Amlodipine 5 mg PO once daily (range 2.5–10 mg).

Recommended BP targets and treatment approach for adults with diabetes and hypertension:

- Blood pressure (BP) goal:
  - Aim for systolic BP <130 mmHg and diastolic BP <80 mmHg for most adults with diabetes who are at elevated cardiovascular risk and can tolerate treatment.
  - A target of <140/90 mmHg is acceptable for others (e.g., older, frail, or those with limited life expectancy) — individualize based on comorbidities, frailty, and risk of adverse effects from intensive lowering.

- When to start pharmacologic therapy:
  - Start antihypertensive medication if clinic BP ≥140/90 mmHg for most patients.
  - Consider starting medication at clinic BP ≥130/80 mmHg for patients at higher CV risk (including many with diabetes), aiming for the lower target if tolerated.

- Initial and preferred agents:
  - First-line agents in patients with diabetes: ACE inhibitor (ACEi) or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), particularly if albuminuria or chronic kidney disease is present — these reduce progression of diabetic nephropathy and provide cardiovascular protection.
  - If ACEi/ARB not tolerated, use ARB (or ACEi if the other was used).
  - Add a dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker (e.g., amlodipine) or thiazide-like diuretic (e.g., chlorthalidone or indapamide) as second-line agents to achieve targets.
  - For resistant hypertension, add agents guided by comorbidities (mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist if appropriate), and evaluate secondary causes.

- Nonpharmacologic measures (always advise):
  - Lifestyle interventions: weight loss if overweight, dietary modification (DASH-style diet, reduce sodium to <2 g/day of sodium or <5 g/day salt), increased physical activity (≥150 min/week moderate), limit alcohol, smoking cessation, and glycemic control. These measures help lower BP and overall CV risk.

Rationale:
- People with diabetes have substantially increased cardiovascular and renal risk; tighter BP control reduces risk of major CV events (stroke, myocardial infarction), heart failure, and progression of diabetic kidney disease more than glucose lowering alone.
- ACEi/ARBs specifically reduce intraglomerular pressure and albuminuria and have proven benefit in slowing diabetic nephropathy and lowering CV events.
- Individualization: Intensive BP lowering (e.g., systolic <130 mmHg) confers greater relative risk reduction in high-risk patients but increases risk of adverse effects (syncope, acute kidney injury, electrolyte abnormalities); therefore targets must be balanced against tolerability, age, and comorbidities.

Possible complications of primary (essential) hypertension and brief management for each:

1. Coronary artery disease (stable angina, myocardial infarction)
- Management: BP control (ACE inhibitor/ARB, thiazide diuretic, CCB as appropriate), antiplatelet therapy (aspirin if indicated), statin for dyslipidemia, beta-blocker after MI, lifestyle modification, reperfusion/PCI or thrombolysis for acute MI, cardiac rehab.

2. Heart failure (left ventricular hypertrophy progressing to systolic/diastolic HF)
- Management: ACE inhibitor/ARB or ARNI, beta-blocker, diuretics for congestion, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist as indicated, treat ischemia, sodium restriction and fluid management, device therapy for advanced cases.

3. Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH)
- Management: Tight BP control (ACE inhibitors/ARBs, CCBs), regression monitored by ECG/Echo, lifestyle changes, treat contributing factors (sleep apnea, obesity).

4. Cerebrovascular disease (ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, transient ischemic attack)
- Management: Acute stroke protocols (thrombolysis for eligible ischemic stroke, blood pressure targets per stroke type), long-term stroke prevention with BP control, antiplatelet or anticoagulation as indicated (e.g., atrial fibrillation), statin, risk factor modification, rehabilitation.

5. Chronic kidney disease (hypertensive nephrosclerosis, progression to end-stage renal disease)
- Management: Tight BP control (target often <130/80 mmHg depending on guidelines), ACE inhibitor or ARB for renal protection (unless contraindicated), glycemic control in diabetics, proteinuria reduction, monitor renal function and electrolytes, refer to nephrology, dialysis or transplant for ESRD.

6. Retinopathy (hypertensive retinopathy)
- Management: BP reduction (gradual to avoid ischemia), ophthalmology assessment, control contributing factors (diabetes), treat malignant hypertensive retinopathy emergently.

7. Peripheral arterial disease (atherosclerotic disease of limbs)
- Management: BP and lipid control, smoking cessation, antiplatelet therapy, supervised exercise program, revascularization for critical ischemia.

8. Aortic aneurysm and dissection
- Management: BP control (beta-blockers to reduce shear stress), urgent surgical or endovascular repair for dissection or large/rapidly expanding aneurysm, surveillance imaging.

9. Hypertensive emergency (acute end-organ damage: encephalopathy, acute pulmonary edema, acute coronary syndrome, acute renal failure)
- Management: Hospitalize, IV antihypertensives (e.g., labetalol, nicardipine, nitroprusside) with careful, controlled BP reduction (generally reduce MAP by ≤25% in first hour unless specific condition requires different targets), treat underlying organ injury, ICU-level monitoring.

General principles across complications:
- Lifestyle modification (dietary sodium reduction, DASH-style diet, weight loss, regular exercise, smoking cessation, limit alcohol).
- Individualized antihypertensive therapy with goal BP per current guideline and comorbidities.
- Regular monitoring for target-organ damage and timely specialist referral (cardiology, neurology, nephrology, ophthalmology) as needed.

Likely differentials to consider when a patient presents with elevated blood pressure (or suspected hypertension) include white-coat hypertension, masked hypertension, secondary causes of hypertension (renal parenchymal disease, renovascular hypertension, primary aldosteronism, pheochromocytoma, Cushing’s syndrome, obstructive sleep apnea, coarctation of the aorta, thyroid disease, drug- or alcohol-induced), and measurement artifacts. Below I summarize how to differentiate each from primary (essential) hypertension by clinical features and key investigations.

1) White‑coat hypertension
- Clinical clues: office BP elevated but no symptoms; home or ambulatory readings normal; often anxious in medical settings.
- Investigations: home BP monitoring or 24‑hour ambulatory BP monitoring (ABPM) — normal out‑of‑office BP confirms white‑coat effect.

2) Masked hypertension
- Clinical clues: normal office BP but high out‑of‑office BP; may have target‑organ changes despite normal clinic readings.
- Investigations: home BP monitoring or ABPM — elevated out‑of‑office BP confirms masked HTN.

3) Measurement error/artifact
- Clinical clues: improper cuff size, incorrect posture, recent caffeine/smoking, repeated rapid readings produce variability.
- Investigations/approach: repeat measurements with correct technique, appropriate cuff, seated after 5 min; if readings normalize, likely artifact.

4) Renal parenchymal disease (chronic kidney disease)
- Clinical clues: history of CKD, reduced urine output, edema, lethargy, known diabetes; often progressive hypertension resistant to meds.
- Investigations: serum creatinine, eGFR, urinalysis (proteinuria, hematuria), renal ultrasound (small kidneys suggest chronic disease). Significant proteinuria or reduced eGFR supports renal cause.

5) Renovascular hypertension (renal artery stenosis)
- Clinical clues: sudden-onset or worsening hypertension, resistant HTN, flash pulmonary edema, abdominal bruit, onset <30 or >55 years, atherosclerotic risk factors.

1. Acute coronary syndromes (unstable angina, NSTEMI, STEMI)

- Management: urgent recognition; hemodynamic stabilization (IV fluids, inotropes, pressors), mechanical support (IABP or other devices), emergent surgical repair.

- Management: intensive care, hemodynamic support (inotropes, vasopressors), mechanical circulatory support (IABP, Impella, ECMO) as indicated, urgent revascularization.

6. Post‑MI pericarditis / Dressler syndrome
- Management: acute pericarditis → NSAIDs, colchicine; Dressler (autoimmune) → high‑dose aspirin or colchicine; steroids if refractory.

- Management: anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC per guidance) for documented LV thrombus; consider imaging follow‑up.

8. Ischemic mitral regurgitation/ventricular remodeling
- Management: optimize GDMT, consider revascularization, valve repair/replacement if severe and symptomatic, cardiac resynchronization if appropriate.

9. Sudden cardiac death
- Management: prevention with risk modification, ICD for high‑risk patients (history of VT/VF or severely reduced LVEF despite therapy), CPR/AED public access for out‑of‑hospital events.

- Management: intensify medical therapy, lifestyle modification (smoking cessation, diet, exercise), consider noninvasive ischemia testing and coronary angiography for revascularization (PCI or CABG) when indicated, optimize secondary prevention (statin, antiplatelet therapy, BP and diabetes control).

Role of revascularization in chronic coronary disease (CCD)
- Goals: relieve ischemic symptoms, improve quality of life, reduce ischemia-driven events, and — in selected patients — improve survival.

When to consider revascularization
- Revascularization is indicated for CCD when symptoms are refractory to guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) and lifestyle measures, or when objective testing shows significant ischemia, or when anatomy predicts prognostic benefit (left main disease, multivessel disease with reduced ejection fraction or large ischemic burden).
- Initial management should optimize GDMT (antiplatelet therapy, high‑intensity statin, beta‑blocker, ACE inhibitor/ARB/ARNI when indicated, antianginal agents) and lifestyle modification. If angina persists or ischemia is high risk on testing, consider revascularization.

PCI versus CABG — comparative outcomes
1. Symptom relief and quality of life
- Both PCI and CABG reduce angina and improve quality of life. PCI usually achieves faster symptom relief and shorter recovery; CABG often produces more durable relief in extensive multivessel disease.

2. Major adverse cardiovascular events (death, MI)
- Left main disease and complex multivessel disease (especially with diabetes or reduced LV function):
  - CABG has demonstrated a survival advantage or lower rates of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) versus PCI in patients with complex multivessel disease and in many with diabetes (e.g., FREEDOM trial) and in selected left main disease subsets.
  - For less complex single‑vessel or focal multivessel disease without LV dysfunction, PCI and CABG have similar long‑term mortality.
- PCI is associated with higher rates of repeat revascularization. Periprocedural MI risk is lower with PCI, but spontaneous MI rates over time may be lower after CABG in high‑risk anatomies.

3. Myocardial infarction and stroke
- CABG tends to reduce long‑term spontaneous MI compared with PCI in complex disease but carries a higher upfront perioperative stroke risk.
- PCI has lower periprocedural stroke risk and shorter hospital stay.

4. Repeat procedures
- PCI has higher likelihood of target‑vessel revascularization (repeat PCI) compared with CABG’s more durable grafting, especially for multivessel disease and diabetes.

5. Specific patient subsets
- Diabetes with multivessel disease: CABG preferred when anatomy suitable (FREEDOM).
- Left main disease: both options possible; decision guided by complexity (SYNTAX score), comorbidities, and heart team assessment. CABG favored for high‑complexity lesions.
- Reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and multivessel disease: CABG often favored for survival benefit.
- Single‑vessel disease, focal proximal lesions, or unsuitable surgical candidates: PCI commonly appropriate.

6. Anatomy and physiology guidance
- Use coronary angiography, fractional flow reserve (FFR)/instantaneous wave‑free ratio (iFR), noninvasive ischemic testing, and SYNTAX score to guide choice. Heart team discussion (cardiologist and cardiac surgeon) is recommended for complex cases.

7. Peri‑ and postprocedural medical therapy
- Optimal GDMT continues regardless of revascularization. Dual antiplatelet therapy duration after PCI and secondary prevention measures after CABG should be tailored per guidelines.

Application to the presented patient
- Progressive angina despite GDMT and likely high symptom burden warrants invasive evaluation with coronary angiography.
- If angiography shows single‑vessel disease suitable for PCI, PCI is reasonable. If multivessel/left main disease or diabetes/reduced EF or high SYNTAX score, CABG likely offers better long‑term outcomes.
- Heart team assessment and shared decision‑making are essential.

Bottom line
- Revascularization is indicated for CCD when symptoms persist despite GDMT or when anatomy/ischemia confers prognostic benefit from intervention. PCI and CABG each have roles: PCI for less complex disease and quicker recovery; CABG for multivessel/left‑main disease, diabetes, or reduced EF where it often yields greater durability and improved long‑term outcomes. Decisions should be individualized using angiographic complexity, ischemic burden, comorbidities, and patient preferences.

1. Risk factor modification

- Weight, diet and exercise: structured counseling, Mediterranean or DASH-style diet, referral to dietitian. Recommend regular aerobic exercise (e.g., 30 min moderate exercise most days) and cardiac rehabilitation.

2. Medical therapy (continue and optimize GDMT)
- Antiplatelet therapy: lifelong aspirin unless contraindicated; consider dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) duration if recent PCI or ACS per cardiology guidance. For some high-risk stable patients, consider adding low-dose rivaroxaban per specific indications (evaluate bleeding risk).

8. Vital signs and focused physical exam, including orthostatic measurements if indicated
- How: measure BP, HR, RR, temperature, O2 sat; repeat frequently.
- Why: detect hemodynamic instability (shock, heart failure) that changes immediate therapy (fluids, vasopressors, urgent reperfusion).

9. Oxygen only if hypoxic (SpO2 <90%), respiratory distress, or high‑risk features
- How: administer supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO2 90–94%; otherwise avoid routine O2.
- Why: routine oxygen in non‑hypoxic MI can increase infarct size; use only if indicated.

10. Point‑of‑care glucose measurement and manage hyper/hypoglycemia
- How: bedside glucometer on arrival and treat per protocols.
- Why: abnormal glucose affects prognosis and medication choices.

11. Consider bedside D‑dimer/CT aortic imaging or bedside aortic evaluation if concern for acute aortic syndrome
- How: if physical exam (pulse asymmetry, new murmur, severe tearing pain) or ECG/non‑diagnostic and high suspicion, get CT angiography chest or bedside TTE assessment of ascending aorta.
- Why: to exclude aortic dissection which can mimic MI and contraindicate antithrombotics or require surgical management.

12. Baseline ECG rhythm strip and 12‑lead post‑reperfusion
- How: capture rhythm strip and repeat 12‑lead after PCI or thrombolysis.
- Why: to document resolution or progression of ischemia and detect reperfusion arrhythmias.

13. Urine drug screen if history suggests drug use (cocaine)
- How: obtain urine toxicology.
- Why: cocaine can cause MI and alters management (avoid beta‑blockers in acute cocaine toxicity without cardiology input).

14. Prepare for reperfusion pathway activation
- How: if STEMI on ECG, activate cath lab for primary PCI (door‑to‑balloon target per guidelines) or assess candidacy for thrombolysis if PCI unavailable; document times.
- Why: timely reperfusion is life‑saving and time‑sensitive.

Summary sequence on arrival: rapid assessment, 12‑lead ECG, chewable aspirin, IV access and bloods incl. troponin, continuous cardiac monitoring and oximetry, bedside glucose, oxygen if hypoxic, serial ECG/troponins, focused bedside echo/chest X‑ray as indicated, and activate reperfusion if STEMI. Each test guides diagnosis (ECG/troponin/echo) or immediate management and safety (monitoring, labs, imaging).

Initial priorities: ABCs, rapid assessment (vitals, ECG, focused history, allergies/anticoagulants), establish IV access, oxygen only if SpO2 <90% or respiratory distress, continuous cardiac monitor, and prepare for reperfusion. Below are the key immediate therapeutic strategies for an acute ST‑elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with timing, dosing, route, and alternatives.

1) Reperfusion therapy — immediate priority
- Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) — first‑line if available rapidly.
  - When: door‑to‑balloon ideally ≤90 minutes (or ≤120 minutes from first medical contact if transfer required).
  - What/how: urgent coronary angiography with balloon angioplasty ± stent to restore flow.
  - Antithrombotic peri‑procedural meds: give loading dose of P2Y12 inhibitor (see below) unless immediate surgery likely; give unfractionated heparin IV per PCI protocol (e.g., 70–100 U/kg bolus, adjust for GPI use).
  - Alternative: If PCI cannot be performed within recommended time windows, proceed to fibrinolysis.
- Fibrinolysis (thrombolysis) — if PCI unavailable in timeframe.
  - When: as early as possible, ideally within 30 minutes of hospital arrival and within 12 hours of symptom onset (strongest benefit if <3 hours).
  - Agents/dosing examples (IV): 
    - Alteplase (tPA): 15 mg IV bolus, then 0.75 mg/kg (max 50 mg) over 30 min, then 0.5 mg/kg (max 35 mg) over 60 min (total 100 mg). (Follow local protocol.)
    - Tenecteplase: single weight‑based bolus (e.g., 30–50 mg depending on body weight) — commonly used because single bolus.
    - Streptokinase: less used due to antigenicity (1.5 million units IV over 30–60 min).
  - Contraindications: recent hemorrhagic stroke, active bleeding, recent major surgery—check carefully. If contraindicated, do not give fibrinolysis; arrange expedited PCI if possible.

2) Antiplatelet therapy
- Aspirin: immediate chewable loading dose.
  - Dose: 160–325 mg chewable PO as soon as possible, then 75–100 mg daily.
- P2Y12 inhibitor (dual antiplatelet therapy for PCI or fibrinolysis)
  - First choice for PCI: Ticagrelor 180 mg PO loading (preferred) or prasugrel 60 mg PO loading if not contraindicated (age <75, no prior stroke/TIA, not low body weight). Clopidogrel 600 mg PO loading is alternative if ticagrelor/prasugrel unavailable or contraindicated.
  - If fibrinolysis given: clopidogrel 300 mg loading (or 600 mg in some protocols) is commonly used; ticagrelor/prasugrel use post‑fibrinolysis varies by guideline and bleeding risk.
  - Maintenance dosing: ticagrelor 90 mg bid, prasugrel 10 mg daily (5 mg if weight <60 kg), clopidogrel 75 mg daily.

3) Anticoagulation
- Unfractionated heparin (UFH) IV or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) per setting.
  - In PCI: UFH bolus ~70–100 U/kg IV (target ACT per lab/protocol) or enoxaparin dosing if PCI not immediate (1 mg/kg SC q12h; initial IV bolus 0.3 mg/kg if transitioning to PCI—follow local protocol).
  - With fibrinolysis: anticoagulation (UFH or enoxaparin) is typically given to reduce re‑occlusion (dose and duration per protocol).
  - Alternatives: bivalirudin may be used in PCI for patients at high bleeding risk.

4) Analgesia and symptom control
- Morphine for severe pain/shock if needed: IV titrated doses (e.g., 2–4 mg IV boluses), but use cautiously: can mask ischemia and may interact with P2Y12 inhibitor absorption.
- Antiemetic (e.g., ondansetron IV) for nausea.

5) Anti‑ischemic therapy
- Nitrates:
  - Sublingual nitroglycerin 0.3–0.6 mg every 5 minutes up to 3 doses for ongoing chest pain if not hypotensive (SBP <90–100), not recently given PDE5 inhibitors.
  - If persistent ischemia and no contraindication, IV nitroglycerin infusion can be started (e.g., 5–10 mcg/min titrated).
  - Contraindicated in right ventricular infarction (inferior MI with clear RV involvement) and with recent phosphodiesterase inhibitor use.
- Beta‑blocker:
  - If hemodynamically stable (no signs of HF, low output, risk factors for cardiogenic shock) give within first 24 hours.
  - Oral metoprolol 25–50 mg PO once, repeat and titrate; or IV metoprolol 5 mg IV every 5 min up to 15 mg total in selected patients with tachyarrhythmia (use cautiously).
  - Avoid if bradycardia, hypotension, heart block, acute heart failure, or high risk of cardiogenic shock.
  - Alternatives: delay until stabilized or give after reperfusion if contraindicated early.
- High‑intensity statin:
  - At presentation or as soon as possible: atorvastatin 80 mg PO or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg PO daily.
  - Continue long term.

6) Heart failure / hemodynamic support (if needed)
- For pulmonary edema/hypoxia: oxygen only if SpO2 <90%.
- If hypotension/cardiogenic shock: consider inotropes (dobutamine) and vasopressors (norepinephrine) guided by ICU/CCU; urgent reperfusion and possible mechanical support (IABP historically, now selective; consider Impella, ECMO in refractory shock) per local resources and cardiology/cardiothoracic input.

7) Arrhythmia management
- Continuous monitoring; treat ventricular arrhythmias per ACLS (defibrillation for VF/pulseless VT).
- Bradycardia with hemodynamic compromise: atropine 0.5 mg IV bolus, repeat to 3 mg total; temporary pacing if refractory.
- Avoid QT‑prolonging meds unnecessarily.

8) Gastroprotection and other considerations
- Proton pump inhibitor if high GI bleeding risk or on DAPT and prior GI bleed (choose PPI compatible with clopidogrel).
- Glycemic control: treat hyperglycemia (insulin infusion if markedly elevated) but avoid hypoglycemia.

9) Post‑reperfusion care and secondary prevention initiation
- Continue dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) for at least 12 months after PCI with stent (duration individualized).
- Start ACE inhibitor/ARB within 24 hours if LVEF ≤40%, heart failure, or anterior MI and no contraindication (e.g., lisinopril 5–10 mg PO daily titrated).
- Continue high‑intensity statin, beta‑blocker, ACEi/ARB as tolerated, counseling and cardiac rehab referral.

Summary order of immediate steps for this stable STEMI patient:
1. Give chewable aspirin 160–325 mg now.
2. Activate cath lab for emergent PCI (aim door‑to‑balloon ≤90 min). Give P2Y12 loading (ticagrelor 180 mg PO) unless contraindicated; give UFH per PCI protocol.
3. If PCI cannot be done in time, give fibrinolysis (e.g., tenecteplase bolus) unless contraindicated, plus appropriate anticoagulation and arrange transfer.
4. Give high‑intensity statin now (atorvastatin 80 mg PO).
5. Manage pain/nausea (morphine/ondansetron), give nitrates if no contraindication, give beta‑blocker if hemodynamically appropriate.
6. Monitor, treat arrhythmias, and plan post‑PCI secondary prevention.

Note: Doses and protocols vary by institution and patient factors (weight, bleeding risk, renal function, allergies). Always follow local STEMI pathway and consult cardiology immediately.

Most likely diagnosis: acute myocardial infarction (STEMI or NSTEMI depending on ECG/biomarkers).

Major possible complications and brief management:

1. Arrhythmias
- Ventricular tachycardia / ventricular fibrillation: immediate ACLS — immediate CPR, defibrillation, antiarrhythmics (amiodarone if refractory), treat reversible causes, urgent reperfusion.
- Bradyarrhythmias/heart block (especially inferior MI): monitor, atropine for symptomatic bradycardia, temporary pacing if persistent/high-grade block, treat ischemia.
- Atrial fibrillation: rate control (beta‑blocker or diltiazem if appropriate), anticoagulation if indicated, cardioversion if unstable.

2. Cardiogenic shock
- Recognition: hypotension, signs of end‑organ hypoperfusion.
- Management: urgent reperfusion (PCI), inotropic support (dobutamine), vasopressors (norepinephrine) as needed, cautious IV fluids if hypovolemic, intra‑aortic balloon pump or mechanical circulatory support (Impella/ECMO) if refractory, ICU care.

3. Heart failure / acute pulmonary edema
- Management: oxygen, diuretics (furosemide), vasodilators (nitroglycerin) if not hypotensive, morphine for severe dyspnea (selective), afterload reduction, treat underlying ischemia, consider inotropes if low output.

4. Mechanical complications
- Papillary muscle rupture → acute severe MR: sudden pulmonary edema, hypotension. Management: emergent afterload reduction, inotropes if needed, urgent surgical repair/replacement.
- Ventricular septal rupture: new harsh holosystolic murmur, acute shock. Management: hemodynamic stabilization (inotropes, IABP), urgent surgical repair.
- Free wall rupture → hemopericardium and tamponade: sudden collapse. Management: emergency pericardiocentesis for temporization, emergent surgical repair.

5. Pericarditis / Dressler syndrome
- Early post‑MI pericarditis (hours–days): pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub. Management: high‑dose aspirin; avoid NSAIDs/steroids in early phase if possible.
- Dressler syndrome (autoimmune pericarditis weeks post‑MI): treat with high‑dose aspirin or NSAIDs; steroids if refractory.

6. Thromboembolism / LV mural thrombus
- Especially with large anterior MI and akinetic LV. Management: anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC per cardiology guidance) to prevent systemic emboli; consider imaging (echo) to detect clot.

7. Ventricular aneurysm and chronic remodeling
- Presents later with heart failure, arrhythmia, thrombus. Management: medical heart failure therapy, anticoagulation for thrombus, surgical repair if symptomatic or risk of rupture.

8. Recurrent ischemia / extension of infarct
- Management: urgent revascularization (PCI/CABG as indicated), optimization of antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulation, statin, beta‑blocker, ACE inhibitor.

General immediate management principles that also reduce complications
- MONA‑B + reperfusion: Morphine (selective), Oxygen if hypoxic, Nitrates (if not hypotensive), Aspirin (chewable), Beta‑blocker (unless contraindicated), high‑intensity statin, antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulation, and urgent reperfusion (primary PCI preferred within guideline timeframes; fibrinolysis if PCI unavailable and within window).

Follow cardiology/ICU protocols and tailor interventions to patient stability, infarct location, and contraindications.

Main differentials to consider (besides acute myocardial infarction) and how to differentiate them:

1. Unstable angina / Non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEMI)
- Clinical: Similar ischemic chest pain, may be less severe or shorter, may have preceding exertion. Risk factors overlap.
- ECG: May show ST-depression, T-wave inversion, or be non-diagnostic (no ST-elevation).
- Biomarkers: Troponin normal in unstable angina; elevated in NSTEMI/MI. Serial troponins (0, 3–6h) distinguish NSTEMI from unstable angina.
- Imaging: Echocardiogram may show regional wall motion abnormality in MI/NSTEMI; less likely in unstable angina.

2. Aortic dissection
- Clinical: Sudden, severe, tearing or ripping chest/back pain often radiating to the back or between the shoulder blades; pain maximal at onset; may have differential blood pressures between arms, pulse deficits, syncope, neurological signs.
- ECG: May be normal or show ischemic changes if coronary involvement.
- Biomarkers: Troponin can be mildly elevated if coronary involvement but not reliably diagnostic.
- Investigations: CXR may show widened mediastinum. CT angiography chest (CTA) or transesophageal echo (TEE) confirms dissection. D-dimer may be elevated but nonspecific.

3. Pulmonary embolism (PE)
- Clinical: Pleuritic chest pain or central chest pain, sudden dyspnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, signs of DVT, hemoptysis possible. Risk factors: recent immobilization, surgery, cancer.
- ECG: Sinus tachycardia, S1Q3T3 pattern, right heart strain (T-wave inversions V1–V4) but often nonspecific.
- Biomarkers: Troponin and BNP can be elevated with RV strain.
- Investigations: CTPA (CT pulmonary angiography) is diagnostic. V/Q scan if CTPA contraindicated. D-dimer helpful if low pretest probability.

4. Pericarditis
- Clinical: Sharp pleuritic chest pain, often positional (better sitting forward), may radiate to trapezius; may follow viral illness. Pericardial rub on auscultation.
- ECG: Diffuse ST-elevation and PR depression (diffuse, not territorial) across leads rather than localized ST-elevation as in STEMI.
- Biomarkers: Troponin can be normal or mildly elevated (myopericarditis).
- Investigations: Echocardiogram may show pericardial effusion. Inflammatory markers (CRP) often raised.

5. Acute heart failure / cardiogenic pulmonary edema
- Clinical: Severe dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, peripheral edema, may have chest discomfort but often breathlessness predominates.
- ECG: May show ischemic changes if ischemic cause.
- Biomarkers: Elevated BNP/NT-proBNP. Troponin may be elevated if ischemia.
- Investigations: CXR shows pulmonary edema; echo shows reduced ejection fraction or diastolic dysfunction.

6. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)/esophageal spasm/peptic disease
- Clinical: Burning retrosternal pain often related to meals, worse lying down; may be relieved by antacids; esophageal spasm can mimic angina and radiate to arms/jaw.
- ECG: Normal.
- Biomarkers: Troponin normal.
- Investigations: Response to antacids, endoscopy or esophageal studies for further evaluation. Consider cardiac workup first if suspicion for MI remains.

7. Musculoskeletal chest pain (costochondritis, chest wall strain)
- Clinical: Localized reproducible chest wall pain, related to movement or palpation, often sharp and focal rather than pressure-like; no autonomic symptoms.
- ECG/biomarkers: Normal.
- Investigations: Clinical diagnosis; imaging only if atypical.

8. Pneumothorax
- Clinical: Sudden pleuritic unilateral chest pain, dyspnea, reduced breath sounds on affected side, hyperresonance.
- ECG/biomarkers: Usually normal.
- Investigations: Chest X-ray (or ultrasound) shows visceral pleural line and absent lung markings.

9. Panic attack / anxiety
- Clinical: Intense fear, hyperventilation, palpitations, chest tightness; often younger patients and situational triggers; may mimic MI.
- ECG/biomarkers: Normal.
- Investigations: Clinical assessment and exclusion of organic causes; consider D-dimer/PE/MI workup guided by pretest probability.

Approach to differentiation in the ED (practical steps)
- Immediate: ABCs, O2 if hypoxic, IV access, aspirin (unless contraindicated), nitroglycerin if pain and not hypotensive, ECG within 10 minutes.
- ECG interpretation: Look for ST-elevation (STEMI), reciprocal changes, diffuse ST-elevation with PR depression (pericarditis), signs of RV strain (PE), or non-specific changes.
- Cardiac biomarkers: Serial troponin measurements to identify MI/NSTEMI.
- CXR: Evaluate for pneumothorax, widened mediastinum, pulmonary edema.
- Bedside echocardiography: Rapid assessment for regional wall motion abnormalities (supports MI), pericardial effusion, or right ventricular dilation (PE).
- If aortic dissection suspected: urgent CTA chest (or TEE) and avoid thrombolysis/anticoagulation until excluded.
- If PE suspected: use clinical prediction rules (Wells/PERC) and D-dimer; proceed to CTPA if indicated.
- If diagnosis remains unclear after initial workup: cardiology consultation, further imaging (coronary angiography if high suspicion for ACS), or targeted tests for other causes (endoscopy, ECG monitoring, esophageal studies) as appropriate.

Key point: Rapid ECG and serial troponins, combined with targeted imaging (CXR, echo, CTA) and focused history/physical, will distinguish most alternative diagnoses from acute MI.

Primary working diagnosis: Right-sided (congestive) heart failure due to prosthetic tricuspid/valve dysfunction or restrictive/constrictive physiology → likely chronic heart failure with right‑sided dominance (possibly prosthetic valve-related or carcinoid/chemo-induced cardiomyopathy).

Justification:
- Progressive orthopnea/orthopnoea and need to sit up to breathe → congestive heart failure.
- Exertional fatigue and reduced activity tolerance → chronic cardiac pump failure.
- Peripheral edema (ankle swelling) and prominent neck veins (JVD) → right‑sided venous congestion.
- Discomfort worse on bending forward and elevated JVP → suggests pericardial/constrictive physiology or right‑sided filling impairment.
- “Square‑wave” response on Valsalva (absence of normal fall in venous pulse/slow y descent) is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis or cardiac tamponade physiology alterations (or fixed RV filling) — supports constriction/tamponade or restrictive process.
- History of prior heart valve surgery (prosthetic valve) raises risk of prosthetic valve dysfunction causing right‑sided failure if tricuspid was involved or long‑term sequelae; prior chemotherapy (cardiotoxic agents) risks cardiomyopathy.
- Hypertension is a background risk for heart failure.

Taken together, the dominant picture is right‑sided congestive heart failure, with constrictive pericarditis or prosthetic valve dysfunction/highly suspected cause given positional symptoms and Valsalva findings. Further evaluation with echocardiography, chest CT/MRI, BNP, and assessment of prosthetic valve function is warranted.

Primary working diagnosis: right-sided (and/or biventricular) heart failure due to constrictive physiology or restrictive cardiomyopathy—most likely constrictive pericarditis given prior cardiac surgery and pleuritic positional symptoms. Significant risk factors from the case:

- Prior heart valve replacement (cardiac surgery) — major risk for constrictive pericarditis/scarring.
- Prior chest radiation/chemotherapy (chemotherapy 5 years ago; if included chest radiation for breast cancer or cardiotoxic chemo agents) — chemo (especially anthracyclines) and/or prior thoracic radiotherapy predispose to cardiomyopathy and pericardial disease.
- Hypertension — risk factor for heart failure and LV dysfunction.
- Age (57) and female sex (relevant to some cardiomyopathies).
- Family history of ischemic heart disease (mother MI) — increases baseline risk of ischemic cardiomyopathy.

Likely working diagnosis: acute decompensated heart failure / right‑sided failure and possible mechanical prosthetic valve dysfunction or constrictive physiology (square‑wave on Valsalva suggests pulsus paradoxus or venous tracing abnormality). Immediate ED tests/monitoring to confirm diagnosis, with why and how:

1. Continuous cardiac monitoring and pulse oximetry
- Why: detect arrhythmia, ischemia, hypoxia, or hemodynamic instability that require immediate treatment.
- How: cardiac telemetry/ECG leads and continuous pulse oximeter at bedside.

2. 12‑lead ECG (stat)
- Why: evaluate for ischemia, acute ischemic changes, arrhythmias, conduction abnormalities, paced rhythm or signs related to prosthetic valve dysfunction.
- How: standard 12‑lead ECG immediately on arrival and repeat if symptoms change.

3. Portable chest X‑ray (AP upright if possible)
- Why: assess cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, pleural effusion, central venous congestion, and position of prosthetic valve/valve ring if visible.
- How: upright AP or PA and lateral if patient can tolerate.

4. Focused bedside transthoracic echocardiogram (point‑of‑care echo) then formal TTE urgent
- Why: evaluate left and right ventricular size/function, valvular prosthesis function (stenosis/regurgitation), pericardial effusion/tamponade, septal motion, inferior vena cava size and respiratory variation, and estimate filling pressures — crucial given orthopnea, JVD, ankle edema and prior valve replacement.
- How: immediate focused POC echo by trained ED clinician or cardiology team; obtain formal comprehensive TTE as urgent study.

5. Cardiac biomarkers: high‑sensitivity troponin
- Why: exclude/identify acute coronary syndrome contributing to acute heart failure or myocardial injury.
- How: draw stat troponin on arrival and repeat per protocol (e.g., 3 hours).

6. B‑type natriuretic peptide (BNP or NT‑proBNP)
- Why: support diagnosis of acute heart failure and help stratify severity.
- How: single blood sample on arrival.

7. Basic bloods: CBC, electrolytes (Na, K, Cl, HCO3), urea, creatinine, liver function tests, glucose, magnesium
- Why: assess renal function (guides diuretic dosing), electrolyte abnormalities that predispose to arrhythmia or affect therapy, anemia or infection, hepatic congestion.
- How: stat chemistry panel and CBC.

8. Coagulation profile and type & screen / crossmatch (if on anticoagulation or possible bleeding risk)
- Why: many valve prosthesis patients are on anticoagulation — need INR to guide management and decide on thrombolysis/anticoagulant reversal if invasive procedures needed.
- How: draw PT/INR, aPTT, and blood typing as indicated.

9. Venous/arterial blood gas if hypoxia or respiratory distress severe
- Why: quantify hypoxemia, hypercapnia, acid–base status and guide respiratory support.
- How: ABG from radial artery if oxygenation/ventilation status uncertain; VBG acceptable for trend if ABG not feasible.

10. Urgent blood cultures and chest infection tests if infection suspected
- Why: infection can precipitate heart failure decompensation; needed if fever/leukocytosis or suspected endocarditis (prosthetic valve history).
- How: obtain prior to antibiotics when indicated.

11. Electrolyte/thyroid tests as indicated (TSH)
- Why: thyroid disease can precipitate heart failure or arrhythmia; electrolytes affect arrhythmia risk.
- How: stat labs per protocol.

12. Assessment for prosthetic valve dysfunction or thrombosis (transesophageal echo or CT as urgent/early)
- Why: prior valve replacement raises concern for prosthetic valve obstruction/thrombosis or pannus — can cause acute heart failure and elevated JVP. TTE may be insufficient; TEE or cine‑fluoroscopy/CT provides better assessment.
- How: urgent TEE arranged with cardiology or cardiac surgery if POC/TTE suggests valve dysfunction; cine‑fluoroscopy for mechanical valve leaflet motion if available; cardiac CT if thrombus suspected.

13. Bedside hemodynamic measurements: orthostatic vitals and jugular venous pressure assessment
- Why: confirm elevated JVP, assess volume status, check blood pressure and perfusion for therapy guidance.
- How: measure supine and sitting/standing BP and HR; inspect and measure JVP at 30–45°.

14. Pulse waveform/arterial line if unstable
- Why: continuous BP monitoring if hypotensive or requiring vasoactive drugs; helps detect pulsus paradoxus or square‑wave phenomena.
- How: place invasive arterial line when indicated.

15. If thromboembolism suspected (e.g., acute dyspnea out of proportion, risk factors): D‑dimer and CT pulmonary angiography
- Why: pulmonary embolism can present with acute dyspnea and right heart strain; must be excluded if clinical suspicion.
- How: D‑dimer to triage (if low pretest probability); perform CTPA if moderate/high probability and renal function allows.

16. If renal dysfunction and diuresis needed: urine output monitoring and urinary catheter if accurate measurement required
- Why: guide diuretic response and fluid balance.
- How: place indwelling catheter if necessary and chart hourly output.

17. ECG monitoring during Valsalva (or invasive venous pressure tracing) if abnormal square‑wave response needs clarification
- Why: to correlate symptoms and abnormal venous waveform with arrhythmia, constrictive physiology or pericardial knock.
- How: simultaneous ECG and central venous pressure tracing if central line present, or repeat Valsalva under monitoring with echocardiographic assessment.

Prioritize: continuous monitoring, ECG, portable chest X‑ray, oxygen, focused echo, BNP, troponin, basic labs, INR, TEE/fluoroscopy if prosthetic valve dysfunction suspected, and CTPA if PE suspected. Manage airway/oxygenation and diuretics/vasodilators per findings while diagnostics proceed.

The key invasive evaluation for patients with heart failure is right- and left-sided cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography (invasive hemodynamic assessment and coronary anatomy assessment). This includes measurement of intracardiac pressures (right atrial, RV, PA, PCWP/LVEDP), cardiac output/index, and coronary angiography to detect ischemia/obstructive coronary disease.

Should it be performed in this patient?
- Yes — invasive hemodynamic assessment and coronary angiography are reasonable here. Rationale: new or worsening heart-failure symptoms (orthopnea, JVD, peripheral edema, reduced exertional capacity), prior valve surgery, prior cardiotoxic chemotherapy, and an unclear etiology (possible ischemic, valvular prosthesis dysfunction, restrictive/constrictive physiology suggested by Kussmaul-like features and a “square‑wave” Valsalva response) justify invasive evaluation to define filling pressures, assess prosthetic valve function, and exclude ischemic disease.  

(Exact timing and choice depend on noninvasive testing results and clinical stability; discuss with cardiology/heart-failure team.)

Immediate therapeutic strategies for symptomatic right-sided heart failure (EF <40%, NYHA class III) should address hemodynamics, congestion, symptom relief, prevention of progression, and treatment of underlying causes. Below is a concise plan with how/when to use each therapy, alternatives if first-line is contraindicated, typical doses/routes, and relevant nonpharmacologic measures.

1) General immediate actions (all patients)
- Oxygen: Give supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO2 ≥92% (or ≥88% in chronic CO2 retainers). Use nasal cannula or mask. Start immediately if hypoxemic or in distress.
- Monitor: Continuous cardiac monitoring, pulse oximetry, frequent vital signs, daily weights, intake/output measurement, and baseline labs (BMP, BNP, LFTs, CBC, thyroid, troponins if ischemia suspected), ECG, CXR, and echocardiography review.
- Treat precipitants: Identify/treat triggers (arrhythmia, ischemia, infection, PE, anemia, valve dysfunction, uncontrolled HTN, medication nonadherence). For suspected acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary embolism, follow appropriate acute protocols (antiplatelet/heparin or thrombolysis/anticoagulation as indicated).

2) Diuretics — relieve congestion (first-line)
- Loop diuretics: IV loop diuretic is first-line for decongestion in symptomatic volume overload (eg, furosemide). Typical initial IV dosing: furosemide 20–40 mg IV bolus in diuretic-naïve or equivalent; if patient already on chronic oral loop, give 1–2.5× their usual 24-hour oral dose IV. If inadequate response, give repeated boluses every 6–12 hours or a continuous infusion (eg, furosemide infusion 5–20 mg/hr) titrated to urine output and renal function.
- Monitor: electrolytes, renal function, urine output; aim for 0.5–1.0 L net negative balance/day initially, more if severe congestion, but avoid hypotension/AKI.
- Alternatives/adjuncts: Add a thiazide-type diuretic for sequential nephron blockade if diuretic resistance (eg, metolazone 2.5–5 mg PO once before loop dose; or hydrochlorothiazide 25–50 mg PO). Consider IV chlorothiazide if oral not tolerated. If significant renal dysfunction or refractory volume overload, consider ultrafiltration (see below).

3) Neurohormonal blockade — improve symptoms, reduce remodeling, indicated for HFrEF (EF <40%)
- ACE inhibitor or ARB: Start unless contraindicated (hyperkalemia, bilateral renal artery stenosis). Typical start: lisinopril 2.5–5 mg PO daily, or enalapril 2.5 mg PO twice daily, titrate every 1–2 weeks to target doses (lisinopril 20–40 mg daily; enalapril 10–20 mg twice daily) as tolerated. If cough or angioedema occurs, switch to ARB (eg, losartan 25–50 mg daily, titrate to 50–150 mg).
- ARNI (sacubitril/valsartan): For eligible stable outpatients with HFrEF already tolerating ACEI/ARB — consider switching to ARNI. Must stop ACE inhibitor for 36 hours before starting. Starting dose varies (49/51 mg twice daily typical) adjusted for prior ACEI/ARB dose and renal function. Not typically started during acute severe decompensation; consider after stabilization.
- Beta-blocker: Start or continue if hemodynamically stable (not in shock, no symptomatic bradycardia). Start low and titrate: bisoprolol 1.25 mg PO daily, carvedilol 3.125 mg PO twice daily, or metoprolol succinate 12.5–25 mg PO daily; titrate every 2 weeks to target (e.g., carvedilol 25 mg BID if <85 kg, 50 mg BID if >85 kg; metoprolol succinate 200 mg daily). If acute decompensation with hypotension/need for inotropes, defer until euvolemic/stable.
- Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA): Spironolactone 12.5–25 mg PO daily (or eplerenone 25 mg daily) in patients with EF <35% and NYHA II–IV, if K+ ≤5.0 mmol/L and Cr within acceptable range. Start after initiation/titration of ACEI/ARB and beta-blocker as outpatient or when stable in hospital.
- Alternatives: If ACEI/ARB intolerant, use ARB or hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate (see below).

4) Vasodilators — for symptomatic congestion with elevated afterload/hypertension
- IV vasodilators (nitroprusside, nitroglycerin): Consider in hypertensive pulmonary congestion and preserved BP. Nitroglycerin infusion 5–200 mcg/min IV titrated; nitroprusside 0.25–10 mcg/kg/min IV in ICU with monitoring. Use with caution if RV infarction or severe hypotension. Not used if SBP low.
- Alternatives: Oral vasodilators (hydralazine 25–50 mg PO TID + isosorbide dinitrate 20–40 mg TID) for those intolerant to ACEI/ARB (especially African ancestry with advanced HFrEF). Start in stable outpatient or inpatient when BP tolerates.

5) Inotropes — for low-output states with hypoperfusion (short-term)
- Indication: signs of end-organ hypoperfusion, persistent hypotension, cardiogenic shock, or severe low output despite adequate filling.
- Dobutamine infusion: 2–10 mcg/kg/min IV (monitor arrhythmias, tachycardia). Increases contractility and may reduce RV afterload via pulmonary vasodilation.
- Milrinone: 0.125–0.375 mcg/kg/min (after loading dose often avoided in hypotension); phosphodiesterase inhibitor, useful if on chronic beta-blocker. Dose adjust in renal dysfunction.
- Use: Short-term (ICU) bridging to recovery, mechanical support, or advanced therapies. Avoid long-term outpatient use—associated with increased mortality.
- Alternatives: Mechanical circulatory support (see below) if intractable shock or refractory RV failure.

- Indication: treat or prevent thromboembolism if atrial fibrillation, intracardiac thrombus, or other indication. - Ultrafiltration: Consider for diuretic-resistant volume overload, especially with worsening renal function despite diuretics. Typically in ICU/interventional unit; remove isotonic fluid and relieve congestion. Requires vascular access and monitoring.
- Right ventricular mechanical support: For severe refractory RV failure, consider RV assist device or ECMO as bridge to recovery or transplantation.
- Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT): For patients with HFrEF, NYHA III–IV, LVEF ≤35% and wide QRS (LBBB, QRS ≥150 ms), consider CRT device implantation after stabilization; can improve symptoms and RV loading indirectly.

- Heart transplant evaluation: For refractory advanced HF despite maximal therapy.

- Daily weights and activity modification: Monitor weight daily; gradual increase in activity as tolerated; avoid heavy exertion during decompensation.
- Vaccination: Influenza and pneumococcal vaccination as preventive care.
- Nutrition and smoking/alcohol: Counsel to limit alcohol, stop smoking, ensure appropriate caloric/protein intake.
- Education and follow-up: Medication adherence, diuretic dosing adjustments, early outpatient follow-up within 7 days of discharge and heart failure clinic referral.
- Palliative care: For advanced symptoms despite therapy, involve palliative team to address symptoms and goals of care.

- Prior chemotherapy: Consider cardiotoxicity (eg, anthracycline-induced) management and closer attention to progression; consider cardiology-heart failure specialist involvement.
- Hypertension and ischemic family history: aggressively treat ischemia/HTN per guidelines once stabilized.
